Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must score the most possible points by filling spaces of an 8x8 board; whole rows and columns add extra points.

Each player throws the die in their turn and ticks with their own symbol (dot, circle, square or cross) as many consecutive spaces on one row or column of the board as pips they've thrown; any free space on the whole board can be chosen to start this segment, but no space on the selected segment can be already marked by the player (different symbols can coincide on the same square, though). Dice throws that can't be used are forfeited.

When every space on the board has at least one symbol the game ends; every symbol scores 1 point and every whole row or column scores extra 5 points.

name: Feu Rouge Feu Vert
description:
Educational game about identifying road signs and observing road safety.

The track is ingeniously designed, going over and under itself at key points. Movement is by dice. At certain points on the track you must answer a question. The answer is hidden from you but if you place a transparent device over it, it becomes visible. You must get a question right to proceed. The first player to reach the end of the track, wins

name: Mange ta soupe!
description:
"Eat the Soup" in English
Players move around the board and try to eat the entire bowl of soup! Otherwise the witch will eat the players! The game can be played both in cooperative or competitive mode.

The game is won if the players have finished their soup before the fourth child is stolen by the witch.

name: Quiz Master
description:
A quiz game for two or more players. Sliding cards have picture clues on one side and questions and answers on the reverse.

Choose a level, easy, medium or hard and push out a card to reveal the picture. Answer three related questions and score the points.

Play against one other person or in teams.

name: Samurai in the Sky
description:
The air to air combat game in World War 2 Pacific theater. This game incorporates technology of the Role Playing Games. Usually played with the game master.

Player(s) control a Japanese naval fighter pilot, and performs various missions. Allied aircraft are operated by the game master.
Each mission is played like a typical air combat game. In addition, players let their pilots could survive, let him gain experience, and aim to survive until the end of the war.
The campaign game will start from China in 1940, then transfer to Philippines and Rabaul, until the end of 1943.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II

name: Speicherstadt Hamburg
description:
Your goal in Speicherstadt Hamburg is to become a Senator in Hamburg during the late 19th century. To do this, you'll buy goods from the ships arriving in the harbor, repackaging some of them to create "donations" (i.e., bribes) to the Senate, while placing other goods onto the market in order to recoup funds needed for future purchases.

The Senate gives victory points for the best three donations. Which one is best? The Senate has different interests each round, which doesn't take into account the price of goods or how often those goods appear.

The players decide simultaneously which cards are gifted to the Senate, which sold at market, and which placed in the storehouse for later rounds. Therefore before the cards are revealed, you know neither whether your donation will succeed nor whether your goods will create enough income for the next round. You do have a lot of information as to which cards are in your opponents' hands, but you never know what they're going to do with them.

At game's end, players with the most money and filled storehouses receive extra points, and the player with the most points wins!
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Trading

name: Ego
description:
Each "Ego" card displays 4 situations and 4 attitudes for each situation to choose..

In his turn player chooses a card and reads aloud the situation in which it is located and the four attitudes that are offered to A, B, C and D. He chooses an attitude for this situation for him.
All other players try to guess together what the reader would have done in this situation and choose one attitude (A,B,C,D)
If they guess the correct attitude the current player had chosen then the player keeps the card and the place before him. If the choice is different, the player loses this card.

When all the 'ego' cards was used, the game is over. The winner is the player with the most points (cards).

EGO is primarily a game of communication. It can be played in a more free, not counting the points. The player is faced with a situation must secretly choose his attitude and sincerely address this situation (among the options set out on his map 'ego'). He has no interest in lying. Other players will then guess what he or she would do in this situation, given their own idea of ‚Äã‚Äãthe person. Finally, the answers are revealed and compared. The comments will then rife about the personality of sometimes surprising each other.

name: Bull Run to Gettysburg
description:
Bull Run to Gettysburg: American Civil War Rules and Campaigns
By David Bickley - 160 pages

Miniature wargame for figures at 25 - 28 mm scale.

Four infantry (4) figures make up a unit. 3-6 units make up a regiment. 4-6 regiments make up a brigade. Two (2) brigades make up a army. Some difference for cavallery, artillery and snipers/sharpshooters.

Troop types comprises infantry, cavallery, artillery and snipers/sharpshooters.

You go/he go - turns. Move/charge, shoot, replenish. D6 dices.
Every unit uses one dice for shooting and one dice for each unit in base contact when close combat is utilized.

There is also a couple of optional rules - Orders, Generals etc.

name: Struggle of Japanese missions to Tang China
description:
This is historical board game based on missions from Japan to China (630-894 A.D.) - see Wikipedia page.

This game was born from a joke title. So Japanese pronunciation of missions to Tang China is "Kentoshi (ÈÅ£Âîê‰Ωø)" as same as Japanese title of Avalon hill's Gladiator (Ââ£ÈóòÂ£´).
Incidentally, its subtitle is "Do You See Jianzhen's Tears!?"

The players either control Japan or Silla (one of the Three Kingdoms in Korea). The game actions is resolved by random chits and dice roll.
Winner is determined by Victory Points: Japan gets points if the mission returns safe, Shilla gets Points if the mission is removed along the way.

First published in Japanese Simulator Magazine renewal #3.
Republished in Wargame Japanese history #19 in September 2013.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Spirit of Shibumi
description:
Spirit (of Shibumi) is a 3-player ball-stacking game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set. It uses a '4x4' holes board and balls in 3 colours.

Each player has an allocated colour, and they take turns during the game (white -> black -> red).

On your turn, place one of your balls on an empty hole or platform so that no other FREE ball (no balls on top) of the SAME colour is on the same row or column of the same level^. If you can't, then you must pass.

If all players pass in a single round the game ends. The player with most balls on the board wins.

Ties are possible, but rare.

Notes from the designer

^- Note that there are 4 levels.

This is an attempt to capture the spirit of Shibumi, by creating a very simple 3-player-only game.

Rules for this game are included in the soft cover Shibumi Rule Book

2-PLAYER VARIANT

2 players. Each player randomly gets 15 balls from a pool of 10 white balls, 10 black balls and 10 red balls.

Play as usual. When no legal moves are available, the player with less balls remaining wins.

name: The Galaxy Corporate
description:
The Galaxy Corporate is a world of trading and piracy for two to four players. Players amass influence by buying planets and trade outposts (or taking them by force) in their quest to become the largest corporation in the galaxy.

A unique economy system combines with a modular board to provide a different galaxy with every game. The laws of supply and demand force players to turn simple buying and selling into strategic economic weapons. Real weapons are also available in the form of ship upgrades and mercenary vessels to turn rivalries hostile.

Will you be a peaceful trading baron or bloodthirsty pirate? The choice is yours in the Galaxy Corporate.

name: Space It!
description:
Draw 12 tiles and place them behind your screen. Create sequences of 3 or more tiles. First person to use all of their tiles wins the game!

During the first round, each player must open by creating a new sequence. After the first round of play, players may create more new sequences or place individual tiles.

A new sequence can be created vertically or horizontally -- in crossword fashion -- but the value between tiles in a sequence must always be equal, such as 3-7-11 (spaced by 4) or 5-12-19 (spaced by 7). TIME WARP: If a player plays a new sequence which contains one tile of each color (red, blue, and yellow), all opponents draw one random tile from the cloth bag.

After their opening turn, players may add new tiles to the front or end of an existing sequence (including another player's sequence), as long as the spacing already established for that sequence is followed. Players may also insert two or more new tiles inside an existing sequence, altering the spacing to a new value between tiles.

Players play as many tiles as possible on their turn, and if they can't play at least one tile they must draw one from the cloth bag. The first player to place all their tiles wins!

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Sequencing, Patterning

name: Air Strike!
description:
Air combat in the 1980's. An extremely simple game (one tiny page of rules) in which the players command the air assets of sectors of a military front. Each has, typically, 15 to 30 planes of various types to allocate secretly to one of four missions (Scramble Ready, Ground Attack, Offensive Air Superiority, Defensive Air Superiority). The allocations are then revealed, and the players determine how many ground attacks succeeded and how many planes were shot down or damaged. Successful ground attacks score 5 victory points, downed planes 2 each.

Scenarios are provided for Germany (U.S. or U.K./Germans vs. USSR), the Mediterranean and the Middle East (Israel vs. Syria).

name: Spoker
description:
Spoker is a game with random elements for the Series: Shibumi game system. SHIBUMI MEETS POKER!

Equipment: the 4x4 Shibumi board and 10 balls of each color (white, black and red). Two players.

Rules

The board starts empty. Players take turns taking a ball at random, for example from an opaque bag, and placing it either on empty board holes or stacking on 2x2 platforms of existing balls.

When a player, with the ball just placed, has formed a visible winning group of balls (see below) he shows it and challenges the opponent, so also the other player takes at random a ball and places it trying to do a group of higher ranking.

The player with the higher ranking group wins the challenge and scores one point. If the two groups have the same ranking, each player scores one point. Obviously if the other player is not able to form a winning group he loses the challenge.
Winning groups can be in any level and also composed by balls placed in different levels. Between two groups of the same ranking, the winner (if exists) is the group with at least a ball at a higher level than the other group.

The game ends when the 30 balls pyramid is complete and the winner is the player with the highest score at the end of the game.
Apex ball can be used only to respond to a challenge, or to form a “straight flush”.

If the placement of a ball creates two or more winning groups, you must always consider the highest ranking group.

When a player has formed a “straight flush”, he wins immediately the game, regardless of the score.

WINNING GROUPS in ASCENDING RANKING ORDER

Three of three kinds: a straight line of three touching balls of different colors, in any order, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Flush three: a straight line of three touching balls of the same color, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Full house: a five balls pyramid formed by two touching balls of the same color and two touching balls of another color in the platform, and a ball of one of that two colors on the top;
Flush four: a straight line of four touching balls of the same color, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Straight flush: a five balls pyramid of the same color.

name: Minions!
description:
Minions! is a strategic race through the woods!
You control a force of creatures and race against your opponent to get 3 creatures to the opposite side of the board.
You can summon Wolves, squash Frogs and use magical Elves to push Turtles into fire.
Each creature has unique, interactive abilities that create different possibilities.
Minions! is essentially an abstract game of movement, with no dice and very little chance. However, unlike many abstract games, there are many different ways to play, and creative strategy is the key to success.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Animals, Bluffing, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Area Movement, Pattern Recognition, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Spodd
description:
Spodd is a two player game with a twist for the Series: Shibumi game system.

Equipment: the 4x4 Shibumi board, balls in two colors. The board is rotated 45 degrees to have clearly seven columns with varying number of balls (1-3-5-7-5-3-1 on the surface of the Shibumi pyramid).

Rules: the board starts with two red balls placed in the left and right corner holes. Two players, White and Black, take turns placing one ball of each color adjacent to each other. The balls can be placed on board holes or on top of 2x2 platforms of existing balls. You can place a ball on a hole and the other on a platform, as long as they touch each other.

Aim: without the left and right corner holes there are five columns with an odd number of balls on the pyramid surface (3-5-7-5-3). When the pyramid is complete, the player with the most visible balls in a column wins that column. The winner is the player who has won at least 3 columns.

Variant for expert players: players score one point when they have conquered a column composed by three balls, two points for a five balls column and three points for the seven balls column. The winner is the player with the highest score.

Note: the game has an odd number of columns composed by an odd number of balls. Ties are not possible.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-a...

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

name: Jerusalem: The Horse
description:
The Builder is a new Action card for Jerusalem.

Just add the card to the basic Action card deck to play with it.

When you play this Action card, place it under one of your squire who's inside one area of the game board. That Squire will have a Horse for the rest of the game. After the first step of phase 3 (The Tower of David), the Squire with the Horse may be moved anywhere on the game board (with the exception of blocked areas by Barons).
Note 1: If an opponent plays "Turncoat", the opponent takes also the Horse!
Note 2: If that squire is removed from the game after a War event or he's killed (the new Assassin card), the card is removed too.

name: Tiens Bon Spider-Man
description:
Similar to Knockout but withou dice.
In order to win: do not let Spider-Man down!
Each player equips an arm and knocked down Venom, and in his turn push one brick out from the wall.
The more skillful player wins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: Deadlands: The Great Rail Wars ‚Äì Derailed!
description: The vehicles supplement to The Great Rail Wars. There are rules for weird science gizmos, steam wagons, and ornithopters and some new scenarios.
categories: American West, Fantasy, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures

name: Empire 4 Viktory II
description:
Empire 4 Viktory II is an adaptation of the classic video game Empire, created in 1971 by Walter Bright.

Empire 4 Viktory II, an unofficial expansion for Viktory II, can be played by 2 to 6 persons. In his turn, each player might generate new resources and units, and give an order to each one of them. Units can move, watch, besiege and build new bases. Bases generate resources capable of creating new units. In Empire 4 Viktory II, the player has 6 kind of units available: Infantry, Tanks, Cargo Ships, Warships, Aircraft Carriers and Bombers. Empire 4 Viktory II uses the fog effect to create an unknown surrounding and hide enemy units for the players.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fighting, Territory Building, Wargame

name: Hacha Mecha Keepers Refrain
description:
User summary
A Japanese home made card game. The players lead a team of nine house keepers through three houses, trying to clear room after room, competing with the other keepers, gaining points. Rooms are laid out in a 6x3 grid and the players attack it from the sides, advancing one room at a time. Each house keeper has a strength of 1–9 and all rooms have a similar difficulty. All keepers also have special powers that can be activated with different timing.
The game relies on planning and when to use the one-time special effects, creating a chaos with virtually no random elements.

Translated box back
The rules are extremely simple! You compare numbers 1 to 9 and the highest number wins! That's all! But in this game, you never seem to win as you think. The interaction between each of the 36 characters' special powers turn the tables in a eyeblink, causing the one who should win to lose and the one who should lose to win.
A simple game, allowing for many different tactics… not to mention the chaos emerging from having several players!

name: Kubbuteo
description:
Kubbuteo is an indoor version of popular garden game, Kubb. Players take turns flicking 6 disks the length of a 4’ by 2’ board, trying to knock down their opponent’s Kubbs [upright disks]. The opponent flicks back the downed Kubbs and then have their turn at flicking the 6 disks at the Kubbs. Once a player has knocked down all Kubbs in the opponent’s half, they may attempt to knock down the centrally located King and thus win the game – but doing this beforehand will result in losing the game, so care must be taken.
Kubbuteo can be played by people of all ages and appeals to players of Crokinole and Carrom, requiring the same dexterity skills. Tactically it is identical to parent game Kubb, deciding where to return downed Kubbs to.

name: Dragon Valley: Hunt for the Fugitive
description:
Hunt for the Fugitive is a BGG Store Promo card that expands Dragon Valley: Rise for Corundia.

Its effect is:

"Choose One:

Move one Friendly or Enemy Unit in your Barony one or two spaces.
Place a purple cube in a built Dungeon in your Barony
Remove all purple cubes in a built Dungeon in your Barony. Score 1, 3, 6, 10 for removing 1,2,3,4 cubes respectively."


It can be added to the King's Aid deck during game setup. It is divided and chosen in the same fashion as other King's Aid cards.
mechanics: Area Movement, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Dragon Valley Tourneys
description:
These mini-games can be used as filler games or during a game of Dragon Valley: Rise of Corundia of 3 or 4 players while two players are waiting for the division of King's Aid. Purple cubes and/or Unit cubes from the Unit bag are used to keep track of game play aspects in Dragon Valley Tourneys.

Players start with Jousting. If finished before the other player(s) have completed the dividing in Dragon Valley: Rise of Corundia, they move on to Archery. If there is still time, they move to the Trebuchet Tourney and afterwards back again to Jousting. If the dividing is complete, finish any score checks but do not continue. If a scoring criteria was not met, no player gains score in Dragon Valley: Rise of Corundia from the current tourney. They do keep the score earned in previous tourneys during this division. Make sure to return any purple cubes to the board and units back into the cloth bag. The next division starts with the next mini-game.

If players are not comfortable playing traditional Rock Parchment Swords, an alternate is to pull Blue, Red and Yellow cubes from the bag and secretly selecting one (if enough are there, otherwise use cubes from the board, but remember where they came from.)
categories: Action / Dexterity, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Medieval

name: Maisy's farm game
description:
All the animals escaped from the barn. We need to help Maisy to get them back.

By spinning the wheel we can either move on the board to find the animals, steal animals from other players, or skip a turn. If you find all the animals on your card, return them to the barn and you are the winner.

name: Passion!
description:
User summary
A fantasy golf themed card game. Players choose different characters and a stage consisting of a series of cards is created. All players start at the first card, and try to pass them in order by playing cards from their hand, by exceeding the stage card level with the card they play. All cards have a specific effect and can be played to hinder other players from advancing.

The player with the most points after 3 stages wins.

name: Starfall Forest
description:
The fairies desperately want to return to their home among the stars. For this they need stardust (the lifeforce of fairies) and what better place to find it than in Starfall Forest?

Every now and then a star will come falling down into the forest where the fairies are hiding and waiting. As soon as a stars lands, the fairies are eager to get to it. Moving from tree to tree, as fairies prefer to stay hidden from sight, they all try to get to the star as quickly as possible. Only when a fairy has collected enough stardust can she make it back home to the stars.

So the race to the stars is on! But beware.. There are venomous snakes about. Try not to get bit as this will cost you the precious stardust you so desperately need to go back home.

All fairies will eventually manage to return home, clever as they are. But who will get there first?
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Spintops
description:
"A Game for Everyone".

The board has a number of holes in it, of varying sizes. In a turn, the player sets off his spinning top in the start area, with the intention of sending it forward towards the scoring holes. If it falls into a hole, points are scored. It follows that the bigger the hole, the less points are gained.

First to reach a pre-agreed total of points, wins.

name: Mera Brainstorm
description: Expansion to the Swedish version of Brainstorm, published by Casper. Contains 360 new categories of 10 words each. Also contains a new rules version introducing the opportunity to challenge an opponent, tweaking step 3, 4, 6 and 7 in the turn.

name: Miniature Air Football
description:
A home version of the arcade game where you use flippers to send the ball to the opposite end of the pitch. This is a reduced size so that it can easily be played on a table.

Both players stand at opposite ends of the pitch. Put the ball in play and frantic flipping becomes the order of the day. Whoever scores the most goals, wins.

name: Spurn
description:
Spurn is a three-player game (inspired by N√©stor Romeral Andr√©s’ Spuzzle) designed for play with a Shibumi set. It uses a 4×4-holed board, and balls in three colors (white, black, and red).

Aim: Be the last player to create a group of four or more balls of your color.

Rules: The 4×4 board starts empty. The players, White, Black, and Red, take turns placing one ball of their own color on the growing pyramid. If you create a group of four or more of your balls, you are eliminated, and will add no more balls to the pyramid.

name: Spruit
description:
Spruit is a solitaire game designed for play with a Shibumi set. It uses a 4×4-holed board, and balls in three colors (white, black, and red).

Aim: Score the most points you can, without losing the game by disconnecting a white or a black the others of its kind.

Setup: The 4×4 board starts with the 16 base holes filled as shown to the right.
The game is played from the 3×3 level up. Empty the bag, and put 5 balls of each color (white, black, and red) into the bag.

Rules: Draw a ball from the bag, and add it to the pyramid according to these rules: When there are no free spaces on a level, you may place the ball on any edge point of the new level; otherwise, you must push a ball from the side with a new ball. White and black balls must end up touching others of their kind; red needn’t do this. If a white or black becomes stranded, you lose. You may not push balls off the pyramid.

Once the last ball is on the pyramid, you score according to the following:
7 points for a visibly connected path of red from corner to corner; otherwise, red is worthless.
A color (black or white) that is split into separate visible groups is worth the product of the number of balls in each visible group of that color.
A color (black or white) that is in one contiguous visible group is worth negative the number of balls in that visible group.
Random Setup: Start with the two red balls in the corner, then put 11 white and 11 black in the bag. Spiral clockwise inward from one of the reds, drawing a ball from the bag and adding it to the board. Now spiral clockwise inward again from the same red, and each time you reach a white or black that is not touching any others of its kind, replace it with the other kind from the bag. (Apologies for the difficulty in replacing the center four!) Note: The base may thus contain more groups than just one white and one black.
After setup, dump the bag, and put the usual 5 white, 5 black, 5 red in the bag to start the game.
When playing with random setup, you should play several games in a row with the same setup, so you can really experience the setup.

Multi-player Solitaire: Any number of people can compete, as long as each person has a Shibumi set. If you do a random setup, everyone should copy one random setup, so everyone starts with the same base. If players can see each others’ pyramids, each player should draw randomly from her own bag during the game; if players cannot see each others’ pyramids, you can have one person draw from her bag the whole game, announcing the color drawn, and the other players simply pull out that color and place it. The latter allows for more pure competition, but the former is often more practical.

name: Volumina
description:
Each player has a set of pieces consisting of different numbers of assembled cubes (resulting in different shapes). Beginning with a random start player, they take turns placing a piece on the base board. The following rules apply:
- A player maynot play the same piece as the other player immediately afterwards
- The piece may not touch the last piece played by the other player
- The piece may not have any parts hanging in the air, reaching over the edge of the board or reach a height of more than 5 cubes.
When a player has managed to get rid of all his/her pieces (or neither player can legally play another piece), the game ends, and the player(s) who still hold pieces count the number of cubes they have left. This is the negative score. After two plays, the player with the lowest overall negative score is the winner.

name: Surf's Up: A Collection of Scenarios for Gaming the Vietnam War
description:
Surf's Up is a collection of scenarios for the Vietnam War designed to accompany the Charlie Don't Surf rules. In addition to sixteen scenarios covering the period 1966 to 1975 there is a campaign system to follow a player's Company Commander through his tour of duty in the 'Nam.

The scenarios are as follows:
1. The Great Rice Hunt, 1966, Operation Attleboro
2. Sniper, 1966, Phu Loi
3. Firebase, 1966
4. Combat Engineer, 1966
5. Fix & Destroy, 1967, Operation Junction City
6. Playing the Beanball, 1967, Quang Ngai Province
7. A County Fair, 1967, Rang Dong
8. Rawhide, 1967, Darlac Province
9. Aircav, 1968, Darlac Province
10. Broken Arrow, 1968, Quang Duc Province
11. Blood on the Streets, 1968, Ban Me Thuot
12. Ambush, 1968
13. Semper Fi, 1968, Hue
14. The Bridge at Tri Ang, 1969
15. The Supermen, 1975, Xuan Loc
16. Convoy of Tears, 1975
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Vietnam War, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: Classic BattleTech: Jihad Hot Spots ‚Äì 3070
description:
For a year, the winds of chaos have scoured the Inner Sphere, as terrorism and weapons of mass destruction are used on a scale not seen since the First Succession War. Confusion reigns, and each faction finds itself isolated amid its own turmoil. All seems lost. Yet as a new decade dawns, glimpses of the greater whole begin to appear through the dark clouds. The true battle has only just begun...

Jihad Hot Spots: 3070 continues the stunning events revealed in Dawn of the Jihad, using the same rolling format and immersing readers directly in the action as never before. Players of both Classic BattleTech and Classic BattleTech RPG will find framework rules to run any type of campaign in regions throughout the Inner Sphere.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Role Playing

name: Nord√©ns auktionsspel: F√∂rsta Andra Tredje
description:
In this game the players take the roles as antique dealers, trading antiquities on the auction market.
There are 42 antiquities in the game, (fairly realistic in their representation with photos and descriptions). The 42 antiquities are sorted in 11 series of 3-5 antiquities each.
The players are to collect them and the one who has 2 (short game) or 3 (longer game) complete series with no outstanding money loans is the winner.

The players start with some cash and 5 antiquities each. All antiquities ar kept secret until a complete series is collected.
as the game progress they move around a board where they land on squares that causes auction to occur; new antiques enter the market, opportunity to loan more money, more money (salary) or random event cards.

The central mechanic is the auctions and the players auction antiquities as well as the bank. Asking price and acceptance price is set by the player. What is to be auctioned, asking and acceptance price is kept secret until the auction starts. Players that win objects include them in their hands and keeps them hidden until a series is completed, (but as the game moves along you can get more and mor knowledge about what the other players have, based on what auctions they won, if you remember this)
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Scratch
description: Scratch is a two-player strategy card game where each player constructs a deck of iconic fantasy monsters. Players take turns laying a single card in a 3x3 grid with each successive card sharing at least one side with a card already in play. When cards are first played, numbers on shared sides are compared to determine if the new card defeats the old card, allowing control of cards to be gained and lost throughout play. Victory occurs when one player controls three cards in a row (horizontal or vertical). Scratch has a minimum of rules but deep strategic game play.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management

name: The Atlantean Wars
description:
the Atlantean Wars boardgame depicts the ancient and mythical war between three all powerful civilizations :
Atlantis, set in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean;
the empire of Mu, set in the middle of the Pacific Ocean and
the Matriarchy of Lemuria, set around the island of Madagascar.

After a long time of peace, and with the oncoming apocalypse, war pits once again those 3 mighty titans, war for the domination of the world, war for the control of the rich zones of Orichalc, this fabulous alloy allowing them to build wondrous machines of war, war for the gaining the alliance of the numerous small nations around the world...
The Empires will be able, to win this war once and for all, to expand their territory with their troops, to build new colonies which will grow in power, to build strange and beautiful wonders allowing for teleport movements, to further their knoledge of technology, all the while battling their neighours and exchanging with them deadly "fire of God" (read nuclear). attacks.

Systemwise, the board depicts the entire world, divided in land and maritime zones.

A turn proceeds as follow:
Initiative phase, where the players determine the order of play for the turn. Do I want to play first, and seize the initiative, launching preemptive strikes and attacks, at the price of acting first during the reinforcement phase, or do I temporize and play second or last.

Tech Phase: each player may advance their tech level by one point, knowing that they have 4 levels of tech possible divided in 4 Elements, Earth (strenghtening their land army), Fire (to make Atomic attack), Water (to strenghten their navy and protection against fire attacks) and Air (for aerial supremacy and range of fire attacks). Each Level of tech give access to new capacities and units. for example, a level 2 of the Fire element give the player the opportunity to launch each turn a fire attack succeding on a 5+ with a 6 sided die. Do I try to proceed in a balance way, or do I specialize in an Element ?

Build Phase : counting their colonies, the alliances with minor powers, the orichalc zones they control, the wonders they have built, the players may then spend their build points to make new alliances, build their cities and upgrading their already existing ones, build wonders, and of course, build their combat units, according to the tech levels they have.

Activation phase: the heart of the game. Each player must, in turn, do one of two things: launch a nuclear attack from one of his colony. If it is successful, and the targeted player do not defend himself with a Water Shield Protection, the area is destroyed once and for all! even if it fails, a unit in the area can potentially be destroyed!
The other possibility is to activate one or two areas and the units they hold. Units begin the turn face down, giving a nice fog of war, and are placed face up once they are activated. Choices must be made once again, do I activate my units early but limiting my potential actions for the rest of the turn, or do I buy time? A fragile balance between those two actions must be achieved. Combat is resolved with a die roll on a differential of strength chart, adding a number of "artefact events" according to the tech level of the engaged units.
During the end phase, the players check to see if a sudden death victory is taking place, that can occur if a player dominates a majority of the orichalc zones, or of the wonders.

The Atlantean Wars is a dynamic game designed for two or three players, with a rich and simple system of play, which can be taught in 20 minutes to a player.

name: Multipuzzle
description:
This is, at first glance, a puzzle but it was always intended to be a game when two want to play.

Inside are 48 plastic shapes and two trays. The puzzle element is that one set of these plastic shapes, 24 in all, must be placed into the tray in such a way that they all fit.

The game is why there are two trays and 48 pieces. Each player has a tray and 24 pieces and it is a race against time to complete the problem the fastest. That player wins.

The box promises that there are 48 puzzles to solve so that should keep a pair of solvers pleased.
publishers: Rocket Toys and Games, Spear's Games

name: Battle of 4 Armies Expansion Kit: The Battle is Joined
description:
From the quick paced, deep decision rich, abstract strategy BattlessonTM game, Battle of 4 Armies, it's expansion kit has finally been brought to the fantastical battlefield. In the Battle of 4 Armies expansion kit: The Battle is Joined, a new Falcon Army spreads its wings and adds another element to the game. Each Hero (including the new army of flying units) now has a set of abilities that are both bold and cunning, giving you that extra chance to be victorious.

How will you sieze the Riverport of Chip? Find out with the Battle of 4 Armies expansion kit: The Battle is Joined!

Note, the Battle of 4 Armies Expansion Kit is not a ‘stand alone’ game. You must own a copy of Battle of 4 Armies to use this expansion kit.

Game Data:

Complexity: 1.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 8.5 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit represents a single troop of fantasy warriors.

Game Components:

• One 1-page, color instructions sheet
• 5 Hero cards
• 10 color, die-cut 1” mounted game pieces
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Zoff am Herd!: Die Erweiterung!
description: This is an expansion for Zoff am Herd! and contains new cards. The expansion is sometimes called "The Brad Worst expansion" because one of the cards is named "Brad Worst". With this expansion you can play the game up to 7 players. The expansion was available in Essen in 2008.

name: Auf dem Weg zum Million√§r
description: A quiz game, designed specifically as a travel game, for a 2 to 20 players, easy to carry and easy to play, you only need paper and pencil or the attached answer sheet. The two issues are separate sections for adults and children, the reader identifies the question number and reads the question and four answers. The players write the answer they think is right on the sheet and lay face down in the middle. If all answers are given, players with the correct answer get one point. Who has the most points at end of the game is the winner
publishers: Dino Entertainment, Dino Toys s. r. o.

name: Schweizer Sammelsurium
description:
Humorous quiz game about Switzerland.
Goal of the game is to reach last station first. You can advance through luck of the dice, correct answers, real wealth, misleading other players and ignorance of the other players.
Players roll the dice and if arrow is rolled he moves up the ladder. If "K", "S" or "W" is rolled player takes a creative, estimate or knowledge card from the deck and asks a question. There is a short game and a team option.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Surviving Design Projects
description:
The hardest part of design isn’t doing the design. It’s working with everyone else without wanting to run screaming for the hills.

Collaborating with smart people on challenging problems is, inevitably, fraught with conflict. Conflict can be good for creative work, moving a project forward as designers wrestle with the challenge. But not all conflict is healthy, and frankly most designers aren’t, shall we say, diplomats.

Surviving Design Projects is, among other things, a little game to help designers hone their people skills. It’s pretty easy. Each player takes turns being the Creative Director. He or she turns over a Situation card, and then tells a little story about the situation shown. She can make it up or draw from her own experience.

Let's say I turn over the situation "Lack of Inputs." Maybe I make up this story:

Though the client has provided stacks of user research, they can’t offer us any clear business priorities. They’re just asking us to make their site better without giving us a sense of what they want to accomplish. I need to go talk to the client about this, and try to get them to give us some inputs.

Each player around the table chooses a Pattern card from their hand and places it face-up next to the situation card. The Creative Director chooses one player to go first and describe how they would apply the pattern to the situation. That is, to describe the technique would they use to make the conflict productive. Let’s say one player uses “Make Educated Guesses” and describes it this way:

The Make Educated Guesses pattern suggests we fill in the holes ourselves with some assumptions. I guess the idea is that we’re smart people, so we should know what the starting point is. We could brainstorm a list of assumptions about the project’s business priorities, then share that with the client to validate it.

The Creative Director then chooses which technique she would use to deal with the situation and leads a group discussion about the choice. The person who suggested the pattern receives the situation card. The player to the Creative Director’s left becomes the next creative director, flipping the top Situation card, and starting again. At the end of the game, the person who has the most Situation cards is the winner.

So that’s it. It’s a pretty simple game, but the idea is to get people talking about difficult situations in a no-strings environment.

name: Arithmetical Croquet
description:
Players take turns saying positive integers less than or equal to 8, but not equal to the number the previous player said, or 9 minus that number, and adding or subtracting that number to a running total. The goal is to be the first player to pass through all ten "hoops" (multiples of 10) up to and including 100. There are two ways to pass through a hoop (a) by saying a number that will reach the opposite side by an equal amount (e.g., if you are at 28, saying 4 will take you through hoop 30 to 32) or (b) by saying a number that lands you in the hoop, and then exiting by the same number on the following turn. If you miss, or are blocked, go back and try again, but you're only allowed to miss the final goal of 100 one time, or else you lose.

One variant allows players an extra move immediately after passing a hoop.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Point to Point Movement

name: YUM: Realtime Icecream
description: YUM is a real-time pattern recognition game where players use an identical startup deck of round cards of different ice cream flavors and must build the proper ice cream cones, in a central location. Once a player believes a cone is complete he selects the cone card and flips it along with all his used ice cream cards. Players can clock-out for additional points once they feel that their remaining ice cream cards can't build more cones, leaving the last player without bonus points. Players verify their cones and discard all incorrect cone cards. All ice cream cards are used again and more rounds are played until the deck of cones is depleated.

name: Absolution
description:
Absolution is a cooperative game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game. To quote the designer:
I like cooperative games, especially "Shadows Over Camelot" by Serge Laget and Bruno Cathala, so I designed Absolution as a cooperative adventure with a Stonehenge theme. Similarly to "Shadows Over Camelot," I wanted Absolution to be difficult, but not impossible to win with the right strategy among the players. Many Stonehenge scholars can agree upon two points: It looks like some sort of astronomical clock, and people died there. In Absolution, the clock is ticking. Whether anyone dies tonight will be determined by you. Save the Druid!

The usual "no telling what your cards are" rule for collaborative games applies. Utilizing a central exchange field to swap cards, players try to set up their hands to be able to play a single card that matches the current turn number (1–30), or a pair of cards whose sum or difference equals the turn number. Your success at doing this determines the pace at which the poor druid walks to the altar to be sacrificed. Don't let it happen!

Absolution is an official game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game.

name: Plus Word
description:
Plus Word is a party word association game. Everyone gets a hand of seven cards, each of which has a word on it. Everyone makes three pairs of words out of these (one is left over), and comes up with a link between them. Then, players reveal their pairs of words. Everyone tries to guess what the other players chose for their link. Players get points whenever they match someone else. The player who's connected the best with other players after a few rounds is the winner!

How would you connect "COLD" and "SCARY"? Maybe you'd think of "YETI." Or maybe "AVALANCHE." Or even "HYPOTHERMIA." It's up to you. But you're also trying to make a connection with the other people playing. Can you get them to think the same as you? Can you think the same as them? The better you can connect, the better you'll do.

name: Starship Command (3rd Edition)
description:
A combined set of Starship Command and Starship Command II with all new artwork.

From the back of the box:

Starship Command is a game of ship-to-ship combat that uses cards to represent ships, damage from ships’ weapons, and other possible ship actions. The objective of the game is to destroy or capture your enemies’ ships while preserving your own fleet. In the basic game each player will have a random mixture of different ships from four or six different races, while in the campaign game a player or team command one race.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Science Fiction

name: Red Ocean: Africa
description:
Red Ocean: Africa is a euro-style board game for 2-4 players, where the players represent investment funds that make money in areas of conflict.

Play high-risk with high payouts. low-risk with low payouts. Combinations. Create monopolies. Dump prices on competitors markets. Influence on conflicts and flee the country if stability changes or a competitor enters. Stop re-investing at the right moment to bring up the cash reserves. Winning this game will require that you master all of these skills.

Each game round represents a year where you have the opportunity to make investments and maximize profits. The investments are kept from year to year, and when one players cash reserves reaches $99 million the game ends.

The gameboard consists of three fictive african countries where investements can be placed. Each country has a conflict scale from 1-6 (1-2=peace) (3-4=unrest) (5-6=war). There are nine types of investments and they pay out differently depending on the conflict status of the country. Some of the investments also affect the conflict status in the country where they are located.

A game round is divided into six phases: 1. Each player can either buy or boost one investment. 2. An event card is drawn for each country and its conflict status might be affected. 3. Each player can move one investment from one country to another. 4. Return on investments are given to the players. 5. Mark investments in competitive situations 6. The "First Mover" token is passed on clockwise.

name: Art Attack!
description:
Art Attack is a tile collecting, market speculation game. Players work to gather tiles from specific artists in a collection and then exhibit their collections for profit when the artist is at their most popular.
Art Attack uses a unique slide device, known as the "MUSEUM" to indicate the current value of a collection. Two paintings by the same artist in the "MUSEUM" mean big profits while a third painting of the same artist floods the market and collections go bust! This forces players to wait consecutive turns for their hard earned collections to hopefully hold value once more.
mechanics: Memory, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Simulation

name: Prism Connect
description:
Japanese collectible card game.
The card game images are captured from Japanese animation (anime).

Deck construction of the game has exactly 40 cards in a deck and can contain only 3 duplicated copies.

The game has 3 card types: Character cards, Event cards and Scene cards. Character cards are the main card type for every activities during the game. The Event cards are once use then discard and Scene cards are used as permanent. Event cards and Scene cards are support cards and only use for trickery during the game.

Each player starts with 25 life point. The player's life point whose become 0 is the loser. The player can reduce the opponent life point by unblocked attacking character card in play. The damage is counted by the character's rank. Almost of them are Rank1 that can deal 1 damage to opponent when it is unblocked.

The game flow is simple. Each player has draw a card at the start of his/her turn and then has 2 main phases and 1 attack phase (battle phase between 2 main phases).
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Uncle Scam
description:
Uncle Scam has its roots in Monopoly but adds to it the effects of Politics and Bribing. The game is won when the first player goes broke and then the money is counted and the winner is declared the player with the most money.
There are Capitol Investments, Rents, Prison, and Bribery but no mortgaging, borrowing, or selling between players allowed.

The game is designed and published by William T. Harvey of Carson City, Nevada, USA.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Star Confrontations
description:
User Description:

Star Confrontations utilizes paper miniatures in a science fiction wargame between armies of deadly warriors. Create an army by selecting which squads and vehicles your warriors will use. Every miniature possesses its own abilities and attributes so your army will always be unique.

This is the core rulebook for Star Confrontations. The rulebook includes two armies: Federation Marines and Orc Raiders.
mechanics: Area Movement, Modular Board, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Chains of Command
description:
Chains of Command is a fast-playing, boardless, luckless, tactical skirmish game. Players build their own armies by mixing and matching units from four distinct factions, and battle in a contest reminiscent of Hive mixed with Heroclix. And best of all, it's currently a free print-and-play game!

With only one neutral tile and a dozen or so hex tiles per army, the game is extremely portable. There are no miniatures to paint, and no sprawling maps to eat up table space. A game can be played in fifteen minutes, and on a surface as small as an airplane tray table.

In Chains of Command, mobility is as important as might, and players must maneuver their units around the periphery of the battlefield, trapping or attacking their enemy, while being careful not to get their own forces pinned or destroyed. If a Commander is destroyed, or an army is unable to use all four of its action points in a turn, the game ends.

Will you play as the heavily armored Crusaders, relying on coordination between multiple units for success? Or possibly the mobile and deadly Saracens? Don't forget the devious Pirates, able to manipulate units in strange ways, or the brutish Natives, who can deal nearly limitless damage. Or create your own motley bunch by choosing from any or all factions you wish.

name: The Most Toys
description:
In The Most Toys, players compete to collect the largest collection of toys before they “die.” Each player starts as a “baby” and uses cards they are dealt to either purchase toys or use their cards to perform actions on themselves or each other. The game ends when all the players are “dead” either by aging naturally through the play of the game or killed or aged prematurely by themselves or their opponents. The winner is the player with the most toys in their possession.

Survival is a moot point as every player has to be “dead” for the game to end.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Economy Chess
description:
ECONOMY CHESS

Economy Chess is alot like normal chess, pieces move the same way and the objective is the same (checkmate the king). The difference is the economy: harvest money from the lands you own, and buy and place pieces strategicaly. Spend -or save- your money wisely!

GAINING INCOME AND PURCHASING PIECES

When your pieces move around they automatically conquer squares. Each square = 1 coin income per turn. Use the coins to purchase pieces and place them in your productionarea. The player may not move in the turn that the pieces where bought. Losing a tempo can be extremely costly.
Managing your money is an important aspect of the game. If you lose ground to much, the opponent can build alot of material. However, if that leads to sloppy positional play you might get mated while being rich!

ECONOMY CHESS 960 (Fischer Random)

Play standard chess with the pieces on your backrank shuffled. Chess960 is the most common chessvariant and can also be played with an economy.

SANDBOX (create your own Economy Chess variant)

In an economy people are stimulated to buy cheaper goods. By adjusting the prices of pieces you can alter the economy to your own will. Or players recieve starting money, giving them a sweet boost.
Adjustig those variables is an easy way to create a handicap. A handicap can be used to make the game challenging when a strong chessplayer plays a lower rated opponent.

name: Zum Gl√ºck gibt's Freunde
description: The friends Franz von Hahn, Johnny Mauser and Waldemar see each other through a lot of adventures. In Variant 1 a players rolls the die to determine the number of tries he has to find a certain tile, depending on what he turns up the turn stone or the player’s stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins. In variant 2 correct tiles are placed on the board, all players win together when all tiles are on the board and the turn stone is not over the finish. In Variant 3 the players piece is moved, then tiles are searched and depending on the result the player’s piece or the turn stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

name: Dablo Aasele
description:
A game within the Dablo(t) family. Related to the Sami boardgame Dablot Prejjesne and to Dablo Daares.

Theme: Abstract game with soldiers and kings

Gameplay: Turnbased checkers type of game

Goal of the game: Either to capture the enemy king or reduce his forces so that only the king remains

Rules: All pieces move by single steps and can capture, by the short leap, in all directions. The soldier ("dårake") can only step in the three forward directions. Promotion does not occur. For the soldier, capture is mandatory. For the king ("gånneka") capture is optional. One can only capture a piece of the same rank or lower. Where the king is of higher rank than the soldier.

A piece moves to an empty adjacent point. If an adjacent point is occupied by an enemy piece, of the same rank or lower, and the point directly behind is vacant, then one may jump over it and capture it, as in checkers. Several pieces may be captured like this in a single turn. Dablo Frostviken follows the same rules. For soldiers a capture is mandatory. For the king a capture is optional.

name: Four Little N***** Boys
description:
NOTE: This game is racist in both name and presentation but is included here for historical interest.

British target shooting game. The targets are four black children, and the aim is to knock them down with a pop-gun rifle that fires corks. The first to reach a pre-agreed total of successful hits, wins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Collectible Components

name: Battlecards: World Conflict ‚Äì Western European Campaign: Expansion Pack 2
description:
Expansion to Battlecards Starter Set: Western European Campaign -- Great Britain vs Germany.

This expansions includes the following:
British King George V Class Battleship
British Radar Detection Device
British Renown Class Battleship
British Southampton Class Cruiser
French Renault R35 Tank
Italian Cavour Class Battleship
Italian Doria Class Battleship
5th Column Conflict Card
Scorched Earth Conflict Card
Battle of Taranto Conflict Card
Battle in Mediterranean Sea Conflict Card

And Extras of:
British Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship
British 6 Pound Gun
British Infantry
German Admiral Hipper Class Cruiser
German Z1934-1936 Class Destroyer
German Flak 37mm
German Flak 88mm
Military Buildup 3/1 Conflict Card
Military Buildup 2/1 Conflict Card
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Tetteretet
description:
In this game you have to make the animal sound that respresents an other player, and an animal sound to ask that player for a card. If you have 3 identical animal card you have a Tetteretet (Sound of a Dutch Elephant).

Make the sound of the animal your are
Say Tetteretet
Make the sound of the set animals 3 times and lay down the 3 cards


The game stops when a player has no cards left.
Winner is de player with the most sets

Horn Card.
When a player is asked for a card he doesn't have, he can give the horncard instead and will receive the asked card in return.

If a player neither has the card that was asked for, nor the horn card, the player makes a mouthfar. The player turn ends and the player takes an extra card from the pile. The game is played clockwise.

A very good game for young children, familycardgame, training material for speech problems. The game gets better later at night. Especially funny in an international setting since animal sound differ in each country.

Published by Sensalot

name: Cubotrix
description:
"In the near future players compete in a strategic boardgame called Cubotrix, a holographic table where a board is displayed and challenge peoples mind to overcame their oponent for the control of board´s areas"

A two player abstract game where players compete in a board made by dices in five different colors. The objective is to control moust of the board dices and create line patterns to score. The board chances every round, with new numbers coming up and others disapearing as the dice change position and faces. Each player needs to combine it´s own dices, hidden from the other player, and pair two numbers that match the same numbers on the board that are adjacent in order to ocupy both dices with one of it´s own control markers. Also players have a set of special actions they can perform once per game that bend the general rules of the game.

Game plays for 45 to 60 minutes.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Pattern Recognition, Variable Phase Order

name: Wong's Game
description:
Wong's Game is a 2 players abstract board game about stone placement and area influence invented by Gary Wong in 1999.

The game is played on an initial empty square board. Additionally each player should have a enough stones of their own color. Alternatively the author suggest that the game can be played with just paper and pencil.

The game is divided in a placement phase and a growing phase:


Placement Phase - Each player, in turns, drops N-1 stones into empty cells (with a NxN board).



Growing Phase - Each player continues to drop stones into empty cells, but now, each stone must have two or more adjacent friendly stones (by "adjacent" it should be understood "orthogonal or diagonal adjacent").


When both players are unable to move the one who has more stones in the board will be the winner.

name: Hexatrix
description:
Abstract game of memory and pattern recognition. Players have two pieces in their hands and each round have to play one piece on the table, creating the board and buy a new piece to their hand.

Each piece is made of 3 connected hexagon, with different colors and shapes. To place pieces on the board, players need to connect at least 2 different hexagons matching or the colors or the numbers, or a mix of both from their hand to pieces already on the table.

Pieces can be placed adjacent to other pieces in the same level or placed over other pieces. Higher a piece is placed, more score a player gets.

Game ends when no more pieces can be added to the board and the player with higher score wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Buzzles
description:
Buzzles is a trivia game about wordplay.
The game consists of 50 cards, each with 3 hints on a neologism created by the combination of two words that sound quite similar.

Players simultaneously try to find the right word. If a player can find the word with only the first hint, he scores 3 points, after the second hint, he gets 2 points and after the 3rd one point.

The first hint is a vague description of the new word (containing attributes of both original words).

The second hint is a synonym for one of the words.

And the third hint is a funny sketch, showing the combination of the words.

name: Berserk Trading Card Game
description:
A trading card game based on the "Berserk" manga series by Kentaro Miura.

The goal of the game is to seize control of 3 of the 5 cities in the game including the capital city or to reduce the cards in your opponent's deck to 0.

This is done by playing character and effect cards at the cities' locations. All cards enter play face-down, even the cities, and you can flip only one card per turn face-up plus one card per battle. Cities are flipped face-up whenever a face-up character is at its location and flipped face-down again when the last face-up character leaves that location. Battles over cities are fought with characters with freely distributable damage in an order determined by the character's range.

Card costs are a mix of payment costs (discarding cards from your hand) and a threshold cost (the number of cities that are currently face-up).
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Collectible Components, Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Frontiers: Sector Kadom Campaign
description:
The Sector Kadom Campaign is a free to print expansion for Frontiers. It was going to be released as official, boxed expansion but the publishers decided against it. It has been posted as free to print on the designers website.

This expansion adds some new units, terrain, weapon types and a campaign with multiple scenarios. The new units including exo-tanks, spiders, a sniper, virus-link and other new infantry and vehicle units. There is also more terrain, such as a garage, hills and more building pieces.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting

name: Nickropolis
description:
Nickropolis is a grave robbing game, where you, as a thief, try to swipe as much loot from the necropolis as you can before you're sealed in forever. The hex card graveyard is laid out differently each game. Move from tomb to tomb, fighting the undead for their treasures, while avoiding traps and the other theives. One word of warning though. You'll want to race to get your goods to the surface. The necropolis locks itself down as you play, so you not only have to collect the loot, you must return to the center periodically and toss the loot up to score it. You can also pickpocket the other thieves if you don't want to fight the undead for it. Nickropolis is a quick, easy to learn, and rather brutal game. If you do join the undead in the tombs, you can still haunt the other thieves and win. Happy stealing!

The Story:

Your buddy Marley motions for you to join him at a dark table crammed in the corner of the bar. You and the other thieves go over and seat yourselves around him. He looks around nervously before he speaks.

"Got a job for you. You know they're planting Ol' Lady Elston tonight? Gonna do some spooky ceremony before they put her in that family necropolis. Listen up. Gatekeeper Willy is in charge of unlocking the mausoleum, and Willy likes his bottle. So I'm gonna make sure he has a nice full one tonight, because that's the kind of guy I am. Once he's hammered, you break in. Got a good map. I'll keep a lookout up top and sort out your loot. Just one thing, you got to be quick. That place has some kind of clockwork mechanism that will seal you down in there with all them dead Elston's, and you don't want that. They say some of them ain't quite as dead as they should be. Now whoever tosses up the most loot items will be known as the king of the thieves around here. You in?"
mechanics: Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Colonial Campaigns: Ethiopia 1887-1896
description:
From the back of the book:

Ethiopia 1887-1896 features 10 action-packed historical scenarios from Italy's only colonial adventure. The Ethiopians, Italians, and the Dervish clash for control of Abyssinia and the port of Massawa.

The scenarios:
1. Lt Cuomo's Advance (The Battle of Saati) - January 18, 1887
2. The Dogali Fight - January 26, 1887
3. The Battle of Gallabat - March 12, 1889 Dervish vs. The Ethiopians!
4. The Battle ofAgordat - December 21, 1893 Dervish vs. The Italians!
5. Fort Halai - December 18, 1894
6. The Battle of Coatit - January 13, 1895
7. Rear Guard at debra-Alia - October 9, 1895
8. Amba Alagi - December 7, 1895
9. The Center Brigades (Adowa) - March 1, 1896
10. Dabormida's Brigade (Adowa) - March 1, 1896

The scenarios are all organized to be played using The Sword and the Flame, but can easily be adapted to any rules set. Units are set at 8 figures instead of the traditional 20. This allows for faster play, greater flexibility and .. your one 20-figure unit becomes 2½ units instantly! Play on either a 6'x4' or 8'x5' table. Give it a try!

Other sections include:
- Uniform Information for the Italians and the Ethiopians!
- History of the period!
- Information on the Italians and Ethiopian armies!
- Campaign Rules!
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Die B√ºrgermeister
description:
Win most mayors in each part of Austria to win the game.
Each round, the player draws a card and follows the resulting event. Afterwards he can place mayors, the first two for free and paying some money for each additional one. With good placement, mayors of other players can be removed, but only two mayors per round and state can be placed.

The player with the most money (cash and value of the placed mayors) wins the game.

name: ATS TT: Battle of the Bulge 1
description:
THIRIMONT, BELGIUM, 15 January 1945: By the end of 1944 the German offensive in the Belgian Ardennes was definitely stopped. But the Allies still had to push the Germans back behind the Siegfried Line before they could resume their strike into the Reich. By January 13—eleven days after it was launched —the counteroffensive had expanded far enough to the east along the battle line to engage the American 30th Infantry Division into the fight, with the capture of St. Vith as a first objective. While its sister regiments were plowing south over the hills, the 120th Regiment was locked in a bitter three-day struggle for Thirimont, a ridge village which controlled the east flank of the attack. By irony of fate, this village was defended by the 1st Battalion of the 9th Fallschirmjaeger Regiment, the same unit, whose soldiers so full of confidence, earlier rode on the tanks of the powerful Kampfgruppe Peiper, and had traversed Thirimont one month earlier on the way to the Meuse bridges.

Here comes an entirely NEW way to enjoy your ATS gaming: Geomorphic boards that link in a myriad of ways! And no one has a cooler scenario collection to put you into the action with on the new boards like CH! Battle of the Bulge I for ATS TT includes all the combat counters and large markers you need to play, just bring your ATS rulebook and play aids and the standard ½" small marker counter sheet and you are ready for this all new take on the Battle of the Bulge and ATS gaming!

name: Tea & Biscuits
description:
How nice it can be to have the simple things in life, like a cup of tea and a nice biscuit to go with it. In this game you will try to make the best combinations of tea and biscuits in order to score the most points.

Tea & Biscuits is a game for 2-5 players where players will create sequences of cards to score points before the card piles run out and trying to complete the objectives available for bonus points. The player who scores the most points is the winner.

name: The Game: Drugs and the Street
description:
The Game: Drugs and the Street is a print-and-play board game in which each player assumes the role of a burgeoning drug kingpin in an urban environment. In the game, each Dealer must gain new corner, sling packages, avoid the police, beef over corners, hire new recruits, build a reputation, defend any threatened corners, and distribute packages.

Using only six-sided dice and a 6x6 grid, The Game should be able to be played with other pieces from games you already own.

In The Game: Drugs and the Street, each Dealer is trying to be the last Dealer still in the game after numerous drug busts from the police or the first Dealer to reach a million dollars starting with humble beginnings.

Every Dealer is out for himself and willing to do anything to get ahead. After all, it's all in The Game.
categories: Dice, Mafia, Mature / Adult, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building, Simulation, Square Grid, Variable Phase Order

name: Toe TacTix
description:
This is a game, along the lines of normal tic-tac-toe, with several difference. First, it features a Toe piece that stuns pieces of players that are adjacent to it vertically or horizontally, so these pieces can't be relocated during the relocation phase. Second, players are limited to only 3 pieces per side. Third, a player can lose the game if they are not able to relocate any of their pieces during the relocation phase of the game.

The name is based off reversing the words "Tic Tac Toe" and using a Toe piece as a blocker.

name: Maya
description:
Maya is a Pachisi inspired racing game with a Mayan theme. Each player has four pieces of identical colors (red, green, blue, or yellow), each marked with a specific symbol (sun, moon, cloud, spears). The board consists of an outer square track and two additional paths, perpendicular to each others, connecting the center tiles of opposing sides of the outer track, thereby subdividing the board into four squares.

The pieces start (sorted according to symbols) at four specific positions at the board. On turn, each player throw two standard D6 dies and accordingly move one or more pieces along the tracks.

The goal of the game is to get all four pieces (of same color) into the corresponding home (located at a specific corner of the board).

name: Racial Wars: Petronus
description:
Racial Wars is the first Polish fantasy card game, designed by ≈Åukasz Kozak. Currently, the game is designed for 2-4 players. However, in the second edition the rules and game sets for 1 player will be presented.

The War of Races takes place in Ithilion world and 12 different races and 1 neutral race take part in it. The goal is to conquer the opponent’s residence or to eliminate his leader from the battlefield. The game also becomes more strategic as you play on two fronts.

Racial Wars in not a collectible card game but thanks to random additions, the player can make his own, exclusive card deck. Each card has its own unique abilities and unrepeatable pictures.

Players start with only leader in front of them and build plateau of cards in front of them - some cards generate resources - different for different races - which are then used to put more powerful creatures into the table. Then, each turn the battle takes place - player who is currently attacking chooses units to attack and defending blocks their attacks with his own to protect his leader. The purpose of the game is to kill enemy leader.

The game is based on a fantasy world of Ithilion, which arose in author’s and his coworkers’ minds. If you want to know the new world and characters living in it, or make a new era in Ithilion world and fight at one of the races’ side, join the Racial Wars community and create with us new days of Ithilion world.

Leader's set "Petronus" is a set which includes the deck of Savands, which is based on a sandy shaman, the creator of time amulets – Petronus.

Savands are a race of desert creatures that live in symbiosis with sand and rocks. They love hot and dry air. Savands race includes creatures made from sand and stone called Seekers as well as powerful worms living under the desert sand.

name: Amos: ƒåe≈°tina v kostce
description:
Amos is a language game using the element of chance in the form of dice roll.

The aim of the player is - after mixing and throwing dices - built from the following letters as many words as they can. Words can be composed either separately or in a cross (as in crosswords). Each letter has a numeric value, so a player who earns the most points during the game wins.

name: Pyramid Crossword Cubes
description:
"The new word game that makes staying home fun!"

Players roll the 15 cubes and set the timer, then try to create as many words as possible on the scoring board (crossword-style) before the timer runs out.

Once time is up, words that were created are scored at a rate of 5 points per cube, with cubes that were not used subtracting 5 points per cube from the score.

Additionally, each cube is placed on top of a numbered square when creating a word, and as each cube is scored, the number that the cube was placed on top of is also added to the score.

So if you have an "R" that is on top of a 7, that cube would score 5+7=12.

Player with the highest overall score after 3 turns is the winner.

The game appears to share a large number of design elements with Scrabble Crossword Cubes, but with a different scoring mechanism.

name: Clang!
description:
Clang! is a combat card game for 2 to 5 players, with great artwork, simple rules, and an easy, numberless game system - ideal for the casual gamer!

PREPARE FOR WAR!
Included in the Core Army Pack are two unique armies, the Army of King Henry Oakenheart (blue), and the army of Emperor Maximillian Ravenclaw (red).

Each card represents a troop of knights and men-at-arms, showing a picture of their commander, with two sets of markings - their battle attacks at the sides, and the peacemaking skills of their commander at the top.

For both of these, the bigger the bar the better! Large bars beat medium bars, beat small bars, beat no bars at all! The same goes for red bars, but red bars always beat white bars, no matter what size.

To battle each player draws four cards and places three cards face down in a row with the long side (side) facing the other player, who then does the same. Turn over troops a pair at a time and compare the combat bars to find out who wins each battle. Loser places their card face down and the winner places theirs face up. The player with the most face up cards wins and collects all face up troop cards (including the other players surviving troops who have changed sides) and puts them in their army.

To have peace talks each player places three of their four cards face down in a row with the short side (top) of each card facing the other player and announces which skill is being challenged. Turn over troops a pair at a time and compare the combat bars of the chosen skill to find out wins each peace talk. Loser places their card face down and the winner places theirs face up. The player with the most face up cards wins and collects all of their face up troop cards along with all face down troop cards of their opponent and puts them in their army.

When your opponent no longer has any troops (no more cards), they are defeated.

Components:
Clang! gamebox Poker Tuck Box (54 cards)
Army of Emperor Maximillian Ravenclaw Deck (1 deck of 25 cards)
Army of King Henry Oakenheart Deck (1 deck of 25 cards)
Poker Deck Instructions Deck (1 deck of 2 cards)
publishers: sinocono GAMES, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Gladiatori: Weapons Set
description: Gladiatori: Weapons Set is a three-card set of additional weapons that's available as a promotional item through preorders of Gladiatori from the publisher Giochix.it.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Corps Commander: By Air & Sea ‚Äì Rules for Air & Naval Landings
description:
This book is a supplement to Corps Commander OMG and that book is required to be used in conjuction with this one.

Extensive rules are included for all airborne operations and in an abstract way amphibious assaults. The army lists include all of the remainder of NATO countries, even Luxembourg! Together with WARPAC air naval assault units. Operations on NATOs Norther and Southern Flanks can now be simulated including overseas reinforcements and special forces.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame

name: Strike Dice Promo Cards
description:
The Promo Tricards are 8 in total and they carry different effects for the 8 Tribases you will find on the game board.

These effects have a great impact during the game since are more powerful. You can use these cards as you do with the original ones in the basic game.

One basic rule applies here: The Tricards you can play must be always 8, 1 card per Tribase. Adding the promo cards we have a total of 16 ( 2 cards per tribase). Before you begin the game choose with your rivals the cards you think are better (8 in total), shuffle them and place them face down in the cantre of the board. Now you can start playing

Last and important: The promo Tricards are language independent. Their effects are included in the card pack!

name: Tsushima
description:
Solitaire wargame for the battle of Tsushima in 1905.
This game published with Japanese history and military magazine "Rekishi Gunzo" #114 the Twenty Anniversary Issue.

Player control Imperial Japanese fleet and fight against Russian Baltic fleet.

The start of the game, player decide turning position against Russian fleet. Then repeat five bombard stage, fire between each other. Japanese bombard resolve with fire-power style combat result table. Russian bombard resolve by random damage chit.

Japanese National victory condition determined by condition of Russian fleet, but player's personal victory condition also affected by condition of Japanese fleet.

name: Morro
description:
Morro is a game for two players on a square grid with white and black stones.

Definitions:
Row: any line of consecutively adjacent, like-colored stones. Rows may be oriented either orthogonally or diagonally. The length of a row is the number of stones in it.
Drop: to place a stone on any empty space.

Rules:

To start, White drops a single stone.
From then on, starting with Black, the players take turns. On your turn, you must drop a number of stones equal to the length of the longest row (of either color) on the board. If there aren’t enough empty spaces left to do so, just fill up the board.
When you create a row longer than any row created by your opponent up until that point, you become the leader.
The game ends when the board is full, and the leader at that time wins.

name: Wortissimo Level 2: Der noch schnellere Wortsport
description:
Even faster word sports than Wortissimo. Are you ready for the next level? The hunt for hidden words continues!

The aim of the game is to explore as many words as possible with given word.
