The players draw a card on which a term is mentioned. For a limited time players should find as many words as possible with the leroll the die with special activities like "R" - the words must be words if reversed etc.

If the hourglass expired, the points (also called Wortissimo) distributed.
There are only German and Germanized terms.

The game types will vary in each period, depending on which letters or numbers rolled. After ten rounds, the points are added together and the one of the most Wortissimo is the winner.

name: BrainBox: Voyage en France
description:
This is a France-themed BrainBox game.

Description provided by the publisher: Do you know where Mont St Michel is? Or where Camembert comes from? BrainBox All Around France contains 53 beautifully-illustrated cards showing the very best France has to offer, and then some! The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner. Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!

name: Kell a g√≥l!
description:
A Hungarian football-themed trivia game. Players answer questions and move their player pieces on a board.

Components: 1 game board, 8 player pieces, 800 cards with 4800 questions, 1 die, game rules

name: Skystrike
description:
Skystrike is a World War 2 Pacific Theater of Operations Nautical wargame cited by the designer as very suitable for novices in that genre.

The game is based on the crucial battle for Midway Island on the 4th June 1942. To win, the Japanese player has to sink the United State's aircraft carriers and thus capturing Midway Island. The American player wins by preventing the Japanese taking the island and inflicting more losses on the Japanese forces than his own suffer.

Each player has their own board and the game thus uses a blind/search system. Only when the enemy is found can combat occur. Each turn represents 8 hours, so three turns per day are the limit. The searching rule owes a debt to dear old Battleships and the board is overlaid with squares so that movement is by square to square.

Once combat starts, results are determined by a die roll. I think there could be very quick combat rounds "Roll a 6 and the enemy carrier is sunk", that sort of thing (it is intended for beginners after all). When it comes to invading the island, the Japanese player gets only one attempt per game so the player must be pretty sure he has timed it correctly.

There are variants - a quick game and an advanced game, plus rules for designating your aircraft as fighters and/or bombers.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hidden Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Square Grid

name: 4 Monkeys: Expansion
description:
Includes 2 mini expansions:

- Blind Monkey, suggested by Vlaada Chvátil.
Cover one of your tiles to avoid giving info about your tiles.
(and make it a bit harder to you)

- Interferences by Toni Serradesanferm.
Interferences are making the test more difficult, they interfere with the available tiles so you never know all of them for sure.

Available at Essen 2011.

Here are the official rules I received by mail from the publisher:

THE BLIND MONKEY
SETUP
Each player takes 1 “BLIND MONKEY” tile and places it in front of him, beside the “Hand replenish” tile.
PLAYING THE GAME
At any time, the players can place their “BLIND MONKEY” on any purchased tile (they cannot place it on the “Discard Hand” tile), so the “BLIND MONKEY” entirely covers it.

The covered tile by the “BLIND MONKEY”:
-Cannot be turned to take 3 more cards
-Cannot be checked.
SCORING PHASE
Before Pass 1, players with the “BLIND MONKEY” not over a purchased tile, place it aside as they do with the wrong combos.
Pass 1.
The players with the “BLIND MONKEY” over a purchased tile, show it to verify if there are repeated tiles.
If the tile under the “BLIND MONKEY” is repeated, the “BLIND MONKEY” is place aside with that tile.
If it’s not a repeated combo, leave the “BLIND MONKEY” on the tile cards, so the tile can be clearly seen.
Pass 3.
If the smartest monkey verifies the tile cards where there’s the “BLIND MONKEY” and finds that they are wrong, he places aside the “BLIND MONKEY” along with the wrong tile.
Pass 4.
If the “BLIND MONKEY” has been placed aside, it counts as -2 victory points as the other wrong tiles.

INTERFERENCES
SETUP
Once there are the combo stacks at the centre of the table, each player takes 1 ”INTERFERENCE” tile and put it above one of these stacks.
During setup, an ”INTERFERENCE” cannot be put above another ”INTERFERENCE”.
PLAYING THE GAME
At any time, the players can remove an ”INTERFERENCE” from above a combo stack and place it above another one. In this way, they can show the combos (on a starting stack or on a single tile that a player set apart during game).
During the game, an ”INTERFERENCE” can be put above another ”INTERFERENCE”.
If only 1 stack remains at the centre of the table (this one with all the ”INTERFERENCE” tiles on it), the players return all ”INTERFERENCE” to the box and the games continues.

name: Tom Mix in Texas
description:
Objective: be the first catching all enemies or capture their headquarter
- moving by turns -
2 players (or groups - red Indians & cowboys) try to catch each other by rolling the die; a '6' can't be used - except on marked (crossed) spaces
remarks:
published during late 1950's
categories: American West, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Fireball Forward: Panzer Lehr at Saint-Lo
description:
The American Army in Normandy is embroiled in the "Battle for the Hedgerows". The key to breaking out lies in capturing the vital crossroads town of Saint-Lo. The US 9th and 30th Divisions have created a bridgehead over the Vire river, the last major obstacle before the town, and are pushing on. The Germans are determined to stop the drive and move the elite Panzer Lehr Division in position to launch a violent counterattack to crush the bridgehead.

In the dark night of July 10th, Panzer Grenadiers, Panthers and Mk. IVs move out to hit the unsuspecting dogfaces.

Follow the action in 15 action-packed historical scenarios!

SS Engineers Battlion Mini-Campaign: Three scenarios featuring elite SS assaulting GI using flamethrowers.

Panther Mini-Campaign: Nine scenarios that follows a company of ten Panthers into the US rear areas battling M-10 Tank Destroyers.

Mk. IV Mini-Campaign: Three scenarios highlighting the US counterattack on the morning of July 11. Hedgerow busting Sherman's battle Mk. IVs.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: RAGE!!!!!
description:
The sun rises on the solstice, and the tribes gather to the ancient battleground. Today, among these hallowed stones soaked with the blood of battles past, it shall be determined who shall rule the land in the year to come.
This is not the time for peace: it is the time for
RAGE!!!!!

A simple tactics game in which you control a group of barbarians, trying to wipe out all opposing barbarians on a battleground littered with druidic stones that can help or harm you. The main mechanic is the eponymous RAGE, which rises with the amount of damage your barbarians take, and makes them more powerful: of course if they take too much damage they still die.

Each barbarian is represented by a custom wood die, with a geomorphic cloth board styled after the designs of Elliot C. Evans.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Neuroshima Tactics: The Outpost ‚Äì Assault Troopers
description:
Assault troopers. Equipped with assault carbines and kevlar body suits are elite among Outpost forces. They are assigned to hardest tasks, as no one else can defend positions as fiercely as they.

Assault troopers set contains 2 troopers, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.

name: Blaster Waves
description:
Step inside a classic video arcade side-scrolling space shooter. Earth is once again at the mercy of on-coming waves of alien attack ships. Luckily, you have the one vessel that can defend the earth from the onslaught. Equipped with your all-important blaster, destroy wave after wave of alien ships and defeat the "Boss" at the end of each level, until the earth is once again safe.

Each Level of Blaster Waves is made up of a "Waves Round" and a "Boss Round". In a Waves Round, the dual-use cards in the main deck are used to setup waves of aliens attacking the player's ship, and also give the player a hand of cards for blasting away at those aliens. The blaster value on the card played from the player's hand is used to remove aliens in the attacking waves. Once the waves have been dispatched, the Boss Round starts where the player has a back-and-forth match with the Boss alien – with the Boss taking an action based on a reveal "Boss Action" card, and the player responding. If the player is able to defeat the Boss, the next Level begins. The player wins the game after defeating the Boss on Level 5.

The game includes Health indicators and PowerUps, such as shields, missiles, bombs, Health improvements, and even a "Wingman".
categories: Print & Play, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Push Your Luck, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game
publishers: Matt Worden Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Aluette
description: Card game played in South-Western France using a latin-suited card deck. This is an easy trick taking game for 2 or 4 players in partnerships where there is no trump suit and no obligation to follow suit. The winner of a trick, is the person who plays the highest ranking card. In the case of a tie, the trick is set aside, and the winner of the next trick takes both tricks. The object of the standard game is to get the most tricks. This game becomes much more interesting by aiming alternatively to get the three of Diamonds, or to avoid getting the Jack of Spades, which can be difficult tasks considering that not all cards are dealt to the players.

name: Kakkuri
description:
This is a traditional game in Fukui-prefecuture, Japan using the variant of Hanafuda cards called "Komatsu-FudaÔºàÂ∞èÊùæÊú≠Ôºâ". Each player tries to get rid of his/her hand of 6 cards. You can play as many card as you want in your turn provided they make the sequence continuing from the previous number. There are some other ways to play 2-3 cards of the same number at once. If you manage to play all 6 cards in one turn then you get double the game point.

The game only works with 7 players. If there are 8, then one person with a particular card sit out.

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Heroes ‚Äì Messenger
description:
Messenger - nothing can stop him. He knows every shortcut, appears and disappears in seconds. Fast and furious - thats Messenger.
Hero is a guy with balls of steel or toughest chick in States. He asks, legions follow.

This set contains 1 mini, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.

name: World War 3: The Board Game
description:
This is a turn-based strategic world domination game with economic/industrial, resource and military planning components. It is currently a proposed Kickstarter project.

There are three main layers to WW3. The first is industrial/economic production. Control the centers of industry, and you earn their production points. However, such control can be gained either through economic investment OR military adventurism. To invade or to invest, that is the question!

The second layer is fuel and resource production. Fuel helps your armies move faster, and your fleets to move MUCH faster. But use up all your fuel on movement, and you may not have much left over for battle. Remember that an army fighting without fuel will be struggling for its very survival.

The final layer to game play is, of course, the military dimension. The basic version of the game will have two types of military units: armies and fleets. Unlike in Risk, where ridiculous numbers of armies start crowding the board very quickly, WW3 forces you to make tough choices with limited military forces. The loss of just one critical army at a key moment could prove lethal; every strategic choice in this game is critical.

name: Black Stories: Die Erweiterung
description:
The game consists of 30 mystery cards, 40 black cards with taboo words and a grim reaper card. The players try to guess the stories behind the scene outlined on the mystery cards without using the taboo words.

Like the other Game: Black Stories games, the central element are the mystery cards. They contain an illustration and a short statement about a spooky or crime event. On the back of the card, the story is presented in more detail. Only one of the players reads the back of the card. The others try to reconstruct how the crime happened by asking yes/no questions.

New about "Black Stories: Die Erweiterung" is that there are cards with taboo words. At the beginning of each rounds, three of these are selected. If one of the players mentions one of these words, the others try to slap the grim reaper card as quickly as possible. The player who correctly slaps the grim reaper card the fastest, wins the taboo card. The person who has contributed most to finding the solution gets the card. The player with the most cards wins the game.

The game can be combined with other games from the series. You can either just use the taboo word cards with other Black Stories instalments, or mix all the cards together.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Horror, Humor, Murder/Mystery, Party Game

name: GoShop!
description:
You and your friends must shop against each other for the finest in designer items: Shoes, Dresses, Make-up, Handbags, and Jewelry. But along the way you will have to avoid credit card declines, maxing out, and store security.

GoShop is a round-the-table dice game. Players take turns rolling the dice to make as many purchases as they can, aiming for the finest designer items. The shopper with the most purchases at the end wins.

name: Mennonite Manners
description:
Mennonite Manners is a simple fun and crazy dice party game. All you need is a sheet of paper per player, one pencil, and one six sided die. The first player to write out the numbers 1-100 wins.

Place the pencil in the middle of the playing area. Players each roll the die in turn until someone rolls a six. That player takes the pencil and starts writing out the numbers 1-100 as fast as they can. The other players continue rolling the die in turn. When someone else gets a six they gently grab the pencil from the player currently writing and start writing 1-100 on their sheet. Continue until someone gets to 100. Numbers may be checked for legibility.

The game doesn't sound like much, but usually generates a lot of laughter, especially when someone is just beginning to write and the pencil is grabbed away. If grabbing pencils sounds dangerous then you can try ringing a bell to stop play in order for the writing player to give the pencil.

name: Flintloque (Third Edition): Bier & Bones
description:
"Beir & Bones" is the 3rd Game Book in a series for the worlds foremost Black Powder Fantasy game; Flintloque. Contains full rules for Character driven Section level skirmish gaming along with full background for the Kartoffelbreg theatre of the Mordredian Wars. Plus Army information for the Nations located thier.

Character creation and Section rules, magicke, skills, traits, flaws both generic and racial specific.

Also Solo play rules and much more.

Flintloque is a tabletop miniature game which takes place in a parody fantasy setting loosely based upon early 19th century Europe and the Napoleonic wars. Features many standard fantasy races such as dwarves, elves, and orcs but also has some unusual races like bunnies, otters, and rats.

Fast playing with minimal bookkeeping, it is a radical departure from previous versions of the game. It is sure to appeal to more casual gamers as well as Flintloque veterans.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Variable Phase Order

name: Kick-Off
description: A simple roll and then read the results of the play, football game from the early 1940's.

name: Wash & Dry Bingo
description: A simple bingo game for young children. Put all the clothing cards into the laundry bag and shake. When it's your turn pull one out. If you have the same picture on your bingo card then you made a match! The first player to match three in a row wins.

name: Ausgerechnet Hamburg
description:
Ausgerechnet Hamburg uses the same game play as the other Ausgerechnet! titles: Players deal three piles of 15 location cards from a deck of roughly 200 cards (naming locations related to Hamburg for this edition), then place an interlude card between each set of piles to make a deck of 45 cards. One location card is placed on the direction board, which has arrows pointing north, south, east and west.

During a turn, a player draws a location card – keeping the latitude and longitude on the back of the card secret from all players – then places the card next to the direction board, indicating how he/she thinks this location relates to the starting one. Is 'Lüneburg' west or east of 'Blankenese'? Why sure, so place it by the west arrow. Location cards can be placed between cards already on the board.

After each location card is placed, any player can challenge the positioning of that card. That player reveals the back of the most recently placed card as well as one adjacent card. If the challenge was correct – and the card placed wrongly – the challenger wins a point chip from the placer and the card is removed; otherwise the challenger hands over a chip to that person.

After 15 cards are placed, the interlude card signals an interim scoring in which all players secretly guess how many cards have been placed correctly. Guess correctly, and you score two chips; if no one is spot on, the closest guesser wins a chip.

After three rounds and the final interlude scoring, the player with the most chips wins.

name: Scrabble: Limited Too ‚Äì Collector's Edition
description:
Back of the box:

America's Favorte Word Game has gone shopping with the Limited Too Edition of SCRABBLE! It's a Girl's World and the classic SCRABBLE crossword game is now played on a beautiful pink game board and includes a special bonus world list to help you score big points and have more fun!

Many of the basic rules from Scrabble apply. Players use their seven drawn letter-tiles to form words on the gameboard. Each word laid out earns points based on the commonality of the letters used, with certain board spaces giving bonuses. But a word can only be played if it uses at least one already-played tile or adds to an already-played word. This leads to slightly tactical play, as potential words are rejected because they would give an opponent too much access to the better bonus spaces.

Variants:
1) Players take 9 tiles instead of 7 and any word that uses 7 or more tiles score the 50 point bonus

2) Play until a player reaches a pre-decided score based on skill level and the number of players.

3) Bonus words! There are 50 different words that when played will score bonus points. 12 which score 5 extra points such as coat, sun, hair, text); 27 which score 10 extra points such as school, flower, ballet, cool, camera); and 11 which score 15 extra points such as stripes, journal, clothes)

name: Run for Your Life, Candyman!: Extra Special Treats
description:
A Publisher-issued promo item for Run for Your Life, Candyman!

Includes the following 11 cards and a cover/ad card labeled
Run for Your Life, Candyman! Extra Special Treats:

100Gs Bar
B.B. Ruthless
Bite-Me-Honey
Frosting
Necrowafer
Nurds
Penny Candy
Sour Patchwork Kids
Spear Mint
2 blank Make Your Own Treat cards


All have Special Treat on the back.

name: Aerochamp
description:
Aerochamp deals with a trans-Atlantic air race. Four players travel from the USA to Europe by balloon. The critical factors in the game are wind and gas.

The wind direction can be determined by the players using tactical cards. The quantity of gas needs to be managed carefully, as otherwise the balloon won't reach Europe and will plunge into the Atlantic Ocean.

Depending on the power and direction of the wind the players choose the optimal flying course. The players who is first to reach the destined port (in Europe) wins the game.

name: Sagario
description:
Over several centuries, four medieval kingdoms disputed the conquest of the Sagario castle, fighting in successive medieval battles. The cycle began every time a kingdom beat the other remaining three in a battle. This winning kingdom enjoyed only a short stay in the castle before the neighboring kingdoms attacked once again. This endless cycle repeated itself constantly — until one day a monk known in the four kingdoms for his wisdom and pursuit of peace, while observing this absurd dynamic of endless battles, decided to end them by creating a board game with the following decree: "The kingdom that manages to capture all the knights of the neighboring kingdoms will be the owner of the Sagario."

Sagario is played on a cross-form board made up of 212 boxes. The Sagario castle is placed in the center of the board game and is surrounded by four towers, which are the landmarks that delimit the territories of the four kingdoms: Sazio, Galia, Risko, and Orbis. Each of these kingdoms has an army of five soldiers and four knights as well as four assault towers to siege the castle. Each player must try to capture all the knights of the bordering kingdoms, at which point he now owns the castle and wins the game.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: Euromind Junior
description:
Junior version of Euromind. The first who reached European Parlament changed its national currency against the euro and won 3 flags during the game wins.

The board represents the European continent with many different spaces. Each player receives 1 contract-card, 3 national currencies and a money in euros.
A player may move his pawn forward paying his visit, he may choose to check back on a bank to earn 50 Euros per square crossed.
Boxes can earn Euros (or make!) 100 € per turn. On the Bank player may exchange its currency against the Euro.
Player can acquire the flags of his contract-card in answering questions about Europe.
The first to join the European Parliament in its possession three flags (and hold more than 100 €) becomes citizen of Europe and win the game.

name: Knot Competitive
description:
A tile based game of building and scoring closed loops
for 2 or more players

CONTENTS:
The game consists of 144 square, double sided tiles, each containing an image of a unique arrangement of one to four white strands. Each strand connects any two of eight positions spaced equally around the perimeter of the square, with no two strands sharing edge positions. The images on the two faces of each tile are mirrors of each other. In addition to the 144 unique tiles there are 6 single stranded tiles that each appear twice, forming a 150 tile set. Tiles have a colored background that indicates the number of strand crossings contained on the tile:
Blue - no crosses - 50 tiles, 44 unique
Green - one crossing - 40 unique tiles
Yellow - two crossings - 30 unique tiles
Orange - three crossings - 10 unique tiles
Red - four crossings - 6 unique tiles
Purple - one each of five, six, seven or eight crossings

OBJECT OF GAME:
The object of the game is to have the highest total points when the game ends.

HOW TO SCORE POINTS:
(1) Each player scores points whenever they arrange one or more tiles, alone or in conjunction with other tiles already played, such that some of the strands on the tiles meet up to form a closed loop. Points scored are equal to the number of times the loop crosses itself or any other strand.
(2) Bonus points are awarded when tiles are placed in such a way as to form a ring of tiles enclosing an empty space. Bonus points scored are equal to the number of free strands pointing into the empty space, but only if it is an even number.

HOW TO PLAY:
1. Each player draws twelve tiles at random from the box.
2. Players attempt to arrange their tiles to form a closed loop. The first to succeed places his loop in the center of the table, counts his score, and then draws enough tiles from the box to return his pile to twelve.
3. Play continues to the left until some player reaches an agreed upon value or until the last tile in the game has been drawn.

RULES OF PLAY:
1. Adjacent tiles must always be placed edge-to-edge and corner to corner, and strands along touching edges must always line up - no dead ends or jogs are allowed.
2. If you cannot build a loop you must forfeit your turn.
3. You may build more than one loop on a single turn, but you cannot place any tile that is not part of a closed loop.
4. If you forfeit your turn you may set aside one or more tiles from your pile and draw new tiles to replace them, returning the others to the box.
5. You may, before placing tiles, swap any tile in your pile with any other tile on the board as long as the swap does not break any closed loop or strand.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: The Amityville Project: Phobos
description:
Friday the 12th, 1964

It is raining today as I stand in front of the Amityville Asylum. I'm here, well because I'm a detective and that's what I do - solve mysteries. This one began when a strange note fell into my possession. Now that I'm here, I don't feel as if I'm alone - the voices are back... Are they phantoms of an insane mind or possibly shadowy thoughts of a deranged personality? Maybe they are all entities living within the world of our detective's mind. In Phobos, each player takes on the role of one of these personalities. Your goal is to eliminate the personalities of your opponent(s). Once accomplished then your personality prevails allowing you to control the detective. Each of you chooses a Mentality board, 8 Ghost Miniatures, 12 Character Miniatures, a D12 Die and 3 Action cards. Players then each get 3 Phobos cards (from 12 different possibilities) and keep these face down. These cards represent your Fears and an extension of the Detective who is imprisoned inside the Amityville Asylum. (Note that the Mentality board includes all the 12 different fears matching the 12 Phobos cards.)

In each round you play an Action card which will instruct you to place your Miniatures either on your board or your opponent's (depending on the card) trying to find their fears. If you place a Miniature on an opponent's Mentality Board that matches one of their fears, they are forced to reveal that fear. Then, based upon how you placed your Miniature you will have accumulated movement points which will be used to place and move your Ghosts on the main board (comprised of 16 tiles). The board includes four central halls where your Ghosts enter the detective's head and 12 fear rooms which represent each of the Phobos cards. When you place 2 Ghosts in a room which represents one of your Phobos cards, you are protected (for as long as they remain). This then makes it so that when an opponent places a Character Miniature on your Mentality board matching one of your fears, you are not forced to reveal your Phobos Card. It sounds simple but nothing is simple in the dream world where nightmares and demons prevail! On the other hand you can play an Adrenaline card and bring the upside down in the game. But these cards cost one of your Ghost, if you to claim one.

If your Fears are revealed by your rivals, then you lose but you are not eliminated. You become a Ghoul that can take revenge on the other Personalities still in play. As a Ghoul you can help control how the game unfolds by playing the right cards and destroying the rival Personalities. You have more advantages like you have more moves or you can even create a modular board. It is time to explore your personality in the ultimate interactive horror game!

Fear is your only god!
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Horror, Memory, Miniatures, Print & Play

name: Insulinde
description: Elaborately illustrated boards table-game featuring the voyage from Amsterdam Central Station via Paris and Genua to the Dutch East Indies. Illustrations featuring trains, Eiffeltower, passengerships and all Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago. Gamers have to pass 68 numerical stations before arriving the final destination. Boardgame with rather complicated rules and touristinfo. about the Dutch East Indies. Drawn and designed by Kees Mandos, dutch painter, draughtsman and graphic artist, copy signed and dated in the stone at tail margin. Very fine copy of this tablegame published under nazi oppression of Holland 1940-1945.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Mist, schon wieder 13!
description:
A card game lonked to characters in a children's TV show in Germany. The most famous character in it, Bernd the Bread, is illustrated on the box.

The six chilipower tiles are shuffled and placed face down. Players are dealt some cards that will have a number on each one, from -2 to +4. A start card is revealed and in your turn you play a card and add it to the start card, announcing the new total. Now next player adds a card and reveals the new total (that is, Start card + previous player's card + his new card). And so the game progresses. If any player takes the total to 13 or more, that player takes one of the 6 Chilipower tiles. The number of chillies on it is bad news because the winner will be the one with the fewest chillies on his chilipower tiles (they range from 1 to 6).

After taking his chilipower tile, the previous round's cards are collected up and put on the bottom of the stack and a new start card is revealed and you play as before. When the last chilipower tile is taken, the game ends and the winner is the one with the fewest chillies.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Brunhilde: Legend of the Galactic Heroes
description:
Tactical level wargame based on Japanese space opera novel and animation, Legend of the Galactic Heroes. This game covering prelude battles of the Amlitzer campaign.

Each players control one star fleet belong either Galactic Empire or Free Planets Alliance.
Each unit represent group of one type of space warship. The units organize to certain divisions, designation by scenario. On the game, players manage movement and combat per each division as same as the unit of the standard wargame, and divisions can not divide or regroup in the play.

Winner determined by eliminate of opponent units.
The game include nine scenarios.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Knights of Ten: Strategic
description:
Knights of Ten: Strategic includes four copies of three new cards that can be added to your Knights of Ten deck. These cards are:


Negate: Negate the last card played.
Draw Two: Draw two cards.
Mirror: Copy the last card played.

name: Giza: Distant Quarry
description:
SETUP: Place the Distant Quarry in front of one of the light-brown Quarries, then place one sled on the new Quarry space on the tile. At this point, place one Base Pyramid Stone on each of the sleds.

Turn order bonus Quarry move: You may alternately take a bonus Quarry Track Advance.

MOVE ACTIONS: In order to get on any sled on the Distant Quarry tile, you must move your workers down the quarry track with the Quarry Track advance option.

Quarry Track Advance: You may move ALL of your workers in one space down the quarry track together.

Return the sled and select new stone: When a sled in this row leaves the Quarry track it is returned to the Distant Quarry in the advanced space.

Was available at Essen 2012: "Game Variants & Mini-Expansions Set #2

name: Der Kleine Prinz: Planet der Zeit
description:
A "The Little Prince" themed game that helps children learn the clock.

Background story: On the Planet of Time the clocks are acting up. This is the evil snake's fault, because she has coaxed the time watchman into turning back the time. Who is going to help the Little Prince and his friends to scare away the snake and bring the hours of the day and night into the correct sequence?

Setup: The starting tile is placed in the middle of the table. The time rays are placed to its sides so that a long time ray from 0 to 24 hours is created (the time rays have numbers from 0-24 printed on them). The hour tiles (showing clocks) are shuffled together with the snake tiles and put face down on the table. Each player gets a character tile and places it in front of him/herself on the table.

Aim of the game: To put as many hour tiles as possible in the correct position on the time ray and by doing so collect as many cogwheel chits as possible. Remembering where the evil snakes are hidden will help you to defeat them and win the game!

Gameplay: The start player puts his/her character tile in a position of the time ray that isn't yet taken up by an hour tile. Then he/she turns over one of the face-down tiles from the middle of the table. If it shows the same time as the position the player has put his/her character tile in (e.g. the character tile is on the "11" position of the time ray and the tile depicts a clock showing 11 o'clock), the hour tile is put in that position, the character tile is returned to the player, and he/she earns a cogwheel chit. If the hour tile doesn't match, the hour tile is returned to its old place in the middle of the table.

If a snake tile is turned over, the player has two options: First, he/she can simply return the snake tile face down to its old place. Second, he/she can return it face up and try to turn over the other two snake tiles. If he/she is successful, he/she immediately wins the game. If he/she isn't, he/she loses a cogwheel chit and then it's the next player's turn.

There are two ways the game can end:
a) The evil snake has been defeated (i.e. a player has turned over all three snake tiles). In this case there are two winners: The player who has turned over the snake tiles and the player who at this moment owns the most cogwheel chits.
b) All the hour tiles have been correctly placed on the time ray. The player who has collected the most cogwheel chits wins the game.

name: Tactical Conflict
description:
Tactical Conflict is an tactical wargame. It's played on a hex boardgame with different futuristic units and cards. With its simple rules, the game is easy to learn and fast to play.

Two players face each other on a 8x18 hexes battlefield. Before the game begins each player chooses cards and buys an army of different units up to a fixed amount of money. The players start on the opposite side of the battlefield. Each player got three actions per turn, where he can command his units or play a card, which affects units or the battlefield itself. There are different hex types like swamp, street, bridge or forest. Some objects like buildings, cliffs and rocks may block the line of sight or can't be entered. Every unit has its special ability, like shooting through buildings for example, or climbing up rocks. Some other objects may give you protection and a hideout. The player who defeats all opposing units wins the game.

name: Trollmaster
description:
User summary
An action selection game with a witch theme and the quirky mechanism that the total number of resources in every player's hands must be enough for you to perform your selected action. The more advanced actions are performed first, so players must try make educated guesses on what resources the other players have.

Actions include to collect mana, summon monsters (which will give you special powers), attack other players (to get points) or simply collect points, among others. What monsters are available for summon varies for each game.

Game ends as soon as any one player has reached 20 points, at which point the player with the most points wins.

name: Arbos XXL
description:
A dexterity game in which players take turns placing wooden branches, leaves and cherries on a trunk that wobbles around. If you knock any pieces off they go into your pile of tree parts. First one to get rid of all their tree parts wins the game.

In addition to the basic game described above, a deck of action cards can be used. Starting with the second round, each player draws a card per turn and follows the instructions (e.g. "place three leaves on your turn", "assign a player of your choice to move a tree part of your choice", "swap your leaves for those of the player to your right).

Arbos XXL is a re-implementation of Arbos. It differs from the regular game in three main aspects: size, a fixed (rather than adjustable) base, and wooden cherries as an additional element. The XXL version was originally intended for nursery schools.

name: Speicherstadt Magistrat
description:
Magistrat is an expansion to SPEICHERSTADT HAMBURG and consists of 35 action cards, which give the players additional options to take control over their success.
The cards are shuffled with 15 Storehouse cards and from that pile you take 10 cards in each harbour phase, one to each package of 2 ware cards to create a three card set. Likewise the basic game each player buys two of these sets in the harbour phase.
New options of the Magistrat cards are for example:
- exchange cards from the sets in the harbour phase
- take your own cards into account only when evaluating the income
- increase the value of your gift to the senate
- get more victory points for your gift
- count MAGISTRAT-cards to get victory points at the end (the more cards the more efficient are they)

The expansion was distributed at Essen 2012 and is now available everywhere you get the base game.
The expansion comes along with short rules. Complete rules are on the website for download.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Expansion for Base-game

name: Shuffle Ball
description: Players have special marbles and the slide on the 3' table. The try to have their pieces stop in the 3-2-1 zone for scoring. The directions state that players may play going the same direction or in opposite directions (unlike similar shuffle board type games).

name: DAM IT the River Conquest Game
description:
DAM IT the River Conquest Game

Great strategy board game DAM IT takes place on a grand river system. With your crew of skilled beavers you will be charged with the task of damming rivers that legends say can’t be dammed. To make matters worse your enemies on the other team will be fighting for the same goal. A good balance of military strategy and well placed dams will be the key to your success. To master this game you will have to use strategy, team work, and just a little bit of luck. During game play you and your team will be faced with tough choices, but don’t be afraid to get wet just make sure you can swim. DAM IT Two Sides… As the game begins, six beaver tribes march onto the battlefield. The Red, Green, and Yellow tribes form the Honored Beaver Alliance, fighting for peace, justice, and wood. The tribes of Blue, Black, and Purple unite to form the Midnight Warriors, fighting to protect the homeland of their ancestors. One Battle… There is an uneasy calm as both teams face each other from across the river. Each tribe raises its flag as the architects discuss their building strategy. The kings stand nobly to ensure victory, and out of the silence comes the command of a warrior: “Charge!” One River. There can be only one victor, the team with the will to Dam It.

The game Dam It is a team game that can be played by 2 players, 4 players or 6 players. Games involving 4 or 6 players are always played in teams. There are 4 ways to win.
(1)_eliminate the kings of opposing players
(2)_capture the dens of opposing players
(3)_dam the end of the main channel river and control it for 6 consecutive allied turns; and
(4)_control 50 or more worker beavers.

Game time: approximately 1 hour

Note: It’s important to spend 10-15 minutes, or so reading the rules carefully. The more time you spend learning the rules, the more fluid and enjoyable the game will be.

The five types of beavers
1. Worker beavers
2. Flag beaver
3. Warrior beaver
4. Architect beaver
5. King beaver

In Dam It, each beaver serves a different purpose and has unique skills. All +1s and +2s are numbers added to die rolls during the combat phase. The combat abilities of these beavers are summarized on the reference sheet under “Combat Statistics”.

1. Worker beavers comprise the bulk of your team. These beavers are easily persuaded. These beavers can collect wood and may be led into battle. The red and blue chips are used to represent the worker beavers of each team.
2. A Flag beaver is an elite beaver that has been trained to repel attacks. To represent this, he is given a +2 while defending. This is the beaver holding a flag.
3. A Warrior beaver is an elite beaver that has been trained in the art of war. To represent this he is given a +2 while attacking. This is the beaver with a Mohawk or with a Viking helmet (for early editions the warrior is also represented by: muscles, snorkel, eye patch, and hair).
4. An Architect beaver is an elite beaver that has studied his/her whole life to become the leader in dam construction. This beaver must be present to construct dams. If the Architect beaver is eliminated, that player can not build dams. This is the beaver holding a book.
5. A King beaver is an elite beaver that is cautious and effective in his war tactics. To represent this he is given a +1 while attacking and a +1 while defending. If this beaver is eliminated from the game, then all other elite beavers from that player are also eliminated, and that player’s turn is skipped for the rest of the game. This beaver is the one with a crown on his head.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Animals, City Building, Fighting, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Team-Based Game

name: Wo sind Schaf & Co.?
description:
Before Framer Bert can take his tractor out in the field, he must quickly feed the animals on his farm. But where are they anyway? They've been hiding in their stables!

In Wo sind Schaf & Co.?, you'll find out who can help Bert find the animals so that he can get on with his work. Whoever has some luck with the dice and good eyes will finish his puzzling animal farm first.

name: H√§uptling Puzzlenase
description:
The cheeky Indian boy Puzzlenase would like to be a brave Indian chief one day, so each day he runs around the village and practices searching for trails that barely exist. Through his curiosity he discovers new things.

In Häuptling Puzzlenase only sharp eagle eyes and a good memory can help you remember and find all that the Indian boy is looking for.

name: Hyperminer
description:
Seeking your fortune, you have bought a mining spaceship, but you have a limited time to pay off the loan. You must fly from planet to planet, obtaining minerals on one before selling for a profit on the next. The blue planet is richer in ore, but you will receive a lower price for the blue than for the relatively rare red minerals. You may purchase upgrades to your spaceship but it will cost you time and money. Can you pay off your loan before the bailiffs turn up?

A solo card game. There is a deck for each of four planets. The player must choose one of four actions - mine, fly, sell, upgrade - then draw a card from the relevant planet deck. Mining and selling will vary in their level of success or failure, depending on the card drawn. Upgrade cards are available which give special abilities. The aim is to earn 160 Credits before running out of cards.

Designed for the 2012 Solitaire Print and Play Contest.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Munching Monsters
description:
This is a free do-it-yourself print-and-play game for parents and kids to use to divide up the variety of Halloween treats they acquire, although any good variety of treats can be used, and not just on Halloween! Playing the game without a decent variety of treats (using generic tokens for treats for example) eliminates much of the fun in choosing which delicious morsels your monsters get to grab from the pot, and steal from other players.

The game is played by rolling 3 custom dice (which have to be assembled from the files included here) in order to roll a MONSTER(s) which then can use the other 1 or 2 dice to perform an action. One-headed and two-headed MONSTERS can GRAB a treat, STEAL a treat, or EAT a treat, for each head they have. A player who GRABS takes a treat from the pot and puts it on their STASH plate, a player who STEALS can take a treat from the pot OR take a treat from another player's STASH. A player who EATS a treat puts it in their STOMACH CONTENTS bag and that treat can not be stolen by any other players. Rolling triples has special effects, like being caught stealing. After all the treats are gone from the pot, players score 1 point for each treat in their STASH and 2 points for each treat in their STOMACH CONTENTS bag. I suggest having at least 10 treats per player to play with. For fairness reasons, sometimes the players agree that if they don't roll at least one monster they can physically eat one treat from the pot.

The dice are made by cutting out and gluing the sides on 3/4 inch wood blocks, or printing them out with adhesive backed paper and pasting them on cubes. The file might have to be re-sized to fit smaller dice; it contains enough icons to fill 6 dice even though you only use 3 to play. If anyone would like to have me make a custom set for them for a little $ I will make them for you. Geekmail me here (NoodleArtist). within a year have a few laser-engraved dice made, and re-release the game with some added rules as a more professional, packaged game.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Magnapoco
description:
from the designer

Magnapoco is a game for 2 players, played with black and white stones on a grid board. You can play on larger grids (they must have an odd number of spaces), but I recommend starting with a 7x7. Good players will swiftly graduate to 9x9.

You want to create, ideally, two large groups without being forced to connect them together, while trying to force your opponent to make small groups in small territories.

name: Breach
description:
from the designer

Breach is for 2 players and is played with Go stones on an initially-empty square grid.

When you take the lead (i.e. when you build a row longer than any built up to that point in the game), your opponent can (optionally) replace one of your stones with her own, in lieu of placing one of her stones on her next turn.

Rules

1. White begins by placing 1 stone on any empty space.
2. Then, starting with Black, the players take turns. On your turn you must place 2 stones on any 2 empty spaces.
3. If you complete a row with a score of at least 2, and that score is higher than any previous score by either player, you must move your scoring marker to that score on the scoring track.
4. After you move your scoring marker, your opponent gets an additional option on her next turn (and only on that turn): instead of placing 2 stones, she may choose to place 1 stone and then replace any one of your stones on the board with one of her own.
5. If the longest row is broken up due to a stone replacement, the scoring marker is not moved back - scoring markers never move backwards.
6. The game ends when the board is full and the player with the highest score on the scoring track at that time wins (in practice the winner will be obvious well before the board is full, and the trailing player should resign at that point).

name: Spry
description:
from the designer

It's a way to solve a problem for a well-known win condition and an excuse to create another game on a colorful board I enjoy (the first was Swaparound). The game is called Spry, which is a contraction of the phrase "Spread Y". The problem is that if you play the game Y on a hexhex board, the center of the board is much more important than the periphery, especially on a small board. Spry is a way to fix that.

It's for two players, played with Black and White stones, on a colorful board.

name: When the Navy Walked Airships and Skypirates
description: Airships and Skypirates! introduces a new threat to the world powers, from the darkness below. Rules featuring all airship or landship combat in the fleet rules, three dimensional combat using advanced rules to add more depth to your game and the Great Powers mighty Airship fleets including the massive Tesla Broadcast Carrier! Contains new rules for airship combat as well as fleet scale using 1/1200 scale miniatures and new edges and flaws!

name: When the Navy Walked: Earthin ‚Äì The Hollow Earth
description: Earthin: A Hollow World features long lost civilizations like the Holy Egyptian Empire, Roma Secundus, Fallen Aztecs, and the origins of the Skypirates as well as the Protean Races that have been here longer than recorded time – the Atlantians, the Devlyn and the Lumerians! Featuring new rules for tunneling and underwater combat as well as new army lists including the use of dinosaurs and prehistoric beasts! With all new dino inspired edges and flaws!

name: Additional Sherlock Holmes Cases for 221B Baker Street, The Master Detective Game
description: Expansion set for the Gibsons Games edition of 221B Baker Street. Rules, Clues and Solutions for cases 41-80. Includes "three-pipe problem" cases - The Mystery of the Mummy's Curse, The Strange Affair of the Missing Major, The Case of the Campanologist's Last Clanger and Sherlock Holmes, the Diogenes Head, etc.
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Murder/Mystery, Novel-based
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Spiel mit Kunst f√ºr Kinder
description:
A game with which children can discover the world of visual arts in a playful way, by answering questions and completing art-related tasks.

Components: 72 picture cards, 91 task tiles, 1 tile bag, 1 sculpture, 24 sculpture parts, 1 learning poster

Each player gets 6 cardboard sculpture parts. The aim of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all their sculpture parts by hanging it onto the tree-shaped sculpture. Players are allowed to hang a sculpture part on the sculpture if they correctly answer a question/complete a task.

24 picture cards with paintings from different eras are put in the middle of the table. On the back of each card there are 3 questions and some general information on the painting and its creator. The task tiles are put in the tile bag. Players take turns drawing a tile from the bag. The active player chooses one of the two tasks and reads it aloud. Now all players try to be the first to complete the task. Tasks include:
- Finding an object (specified on the task tile) on one of the picture cards.
- The active player describes a picture, the other players try to guess which one it is.
- The active player tries to draw one of the pictures, the others guess.
- Players have to answer a question on one of the cards (cards are turned face down).
- Guessing which painting is the oldest or most recent.

The game ends when one of the players has managed to get rid of all his/her sculpture parts.

name: Clots
description:
from designer's site:

The game is played on a Hexhex board divided into concentric sections. I don't know the best board size, and I don't yet know the best way to section the board. The different versions of the game arise from the different ways to section the board. I'll start by describing the rules with the simplest board.

Rules

1. The board begins empty. One player owns the black stones, and the other owns the white. Starting with Black, the players take turns.
2. On your turn, you must either place one stone on any empty space on the inner section, or two stones on any two empty spaces in the outer section.
3. The game ends when the board is full. The player with the largest group wins. If the players’ largest groups are the same size, compare their second-largest groups, and so on, until you come to a pair which aren't the same size. Whoever owns the larger of the two wins.

name: Swaparound
description:
from the designer's site:

It has a novel mechanism with some aesthetic appeal, along with a festive board. It's a variant of Y on a hexhex board, but with a balancing twist. It's for two players, played with white and black stones on the board [used by Spry].

The board consists of blue, red, and yellow borders, as well as concentric rings, each a different shade of green. The central space is also considered a “ring”, even though it’s just one space.

Rules

1. The board begins empty.
2. The players take turns. On each turn, a player must place one stone of her color onto any empty space, but not on any red, yellow or blue spaces.
3. If a player makes a first placement on a ring interior to all other rings with stones currently on them, then her opponent may optionally switch sides with her, rather than place a stone, on his next turn.
4. The game ends when a chain of either white or black stones touches at least one red, one yellow, and one blue space. The player who owns that chain at game’s end wins.

name: Population Pressure
description:
from the designer's website:

Two tribes are competing for territory by breeding. Couples make babies. My most thematic game :)

Population Pressure is a game for 2 players, played on a hexhex board. I recommend Hexhex5 to start.

Rules

1. The board begins empty.
2. To begin, one player places one white and one black stone on any vacant spaces on the board, and the other player decides whether to play as White or Black.
3. Starting with Black, the players take turns. You may place one stone on any vacant space on each turn, until you have a group on the board of size 2 or larger. After that, on your turn you may place as many stones on vacant spaces as you have groups of size 2 or larger on the board.
4. The game ends when the board is full, and the player with the largest group wins. If the players’ largest groups are the same size, the player with the fewest stones on the board wins.

On larger boards, you might experiment with higher minimum group sizes (polyamory?)

name: Marauders of the Rift
description:
From the publisher website:

"Marauders, pirates, raiders, corsairs, call them what you will, this full colour Firestorm Armada Campaign Guide delivers to you page-after-page of thrilling information to take your space combat games to a new level."

Six new factions are introduced: The Syndacate, OmnyDine, The Rift Traders League, Supermax-89, the Corsairs, Pathogen X9-V.
Along them statistics for numerous new space vehicles, mercenary fleets are provided, as new in-game mechanics, a full campaign background and8 new tabletop scenarios.

Paperback, full color.

name: Malifaux: Kaeris Starter Box
description: This box set expands the number and type of units available for Malifaux by adding the Kaeris crew. The set contains Kaeris, 2 Gunsmiths, and 3 Red Gamlins.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Malifaux: Lilith's Brood
description: This box set expands the number and type of units available for Malifaux by adding the Lilith's Brood crew. The set contains Lilith (leader), 1 mature Nephilim, and 3 Terror Tot Nephilims.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Sapos
description:
Sapos is played with 32 bi-colored pieces on an 8×8 board with the following setup:

Two players Dark and Light. Each player has 4 pieces on the board and 12 in reserve.

Dark’s 4 pieces are placed on the points d2, d3,e2,e3, and Light’s 4 pieces are placed on d6,d7,e6,e7

Players take turns performing any number of these actions:

1) hop over an orthogonally or diagonally adjacent friend into an empty square.

2) jump over an orthogonally adjacent enemy into an empty square, capturing the jumped enemy and placing it into your reserve.

3) spawn a piece from your reserve by placing it in an empty square orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to the last hop

There are some rules for the flow of a turn:

1) You will only ever hop and jump' with a single piece during your turn.

2) If you have a 2x2 formation of pieces at the start of your turn, you must move with one of those pieces.

3) You can hop and jump multiple times.

4) Once you make a jump you may no longer hop.

5) If you don't make a jump you must end your turn with a spawn.

6) After Player 2's first turn she must immediately move again. Neither sequence may contain a jump.

Here are some examples of valid turns:

hop, spawn
hop, hop, hop, spawn
jump
hop, hop, jump, jump

And Player 2's first turn likely looks like this:

hop, spawn, hop, spawn

If your opponent is unable to finish her next turn, you win by starvation!

This win condition means that if you have 0 in reserve at the start of your turn then you must jump since you otherwise cannot afford to spawn.

You can play at
http://chessicals.com/
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Grid Movement

name: Geisterturm
description:
This game is similar to the dexterity classic Ker Plunk. Sticks have to be removed without wooden ghost figures tumbling down.

Setup:
Clear plastic sheets are put on the sides of a wooden castle towers. Wooden sticks are then put through holes in the plastic so that they cross the tower. Wooden ghosts (in black, white and orange) are put on top of the sticks.

Gameplay:
A six-sided number die is rolled to determine the start player. Players then take turns rolling a six-sided colour die. The active player has to remove a stick marked with the colour determined by the die roll. Then it is the next player's turn.

Aim of the game:
Removing as many sticks as possible without a ghost falling on the tower floor. If a ghost hits the floor, the player responsible loses a turn. Players keep the sticks they removed and any ghosts they caused to fall. At the end of the game, points are counted as follows: Each stick is worth one point. Each white ghost counts one minus point, orange ghosts two minus points and black ghosts 7 minus points. The player with the most points wins the game.

name: Komm mit in Millys Lernzoo
description:
A cooperative, zoo-themed educational game for children aged 2+ in which they get to know the numbers 1-3 as well as some shapes and colours in a playful way.

Background story:
Milly, the animal keeper, has lots of work today. She has to deliver the mail to the bear, the two lions and the three elephants, bring them food or paint the animal houses. And Dapdap, the penguin, has escaped from his enclosure and visits all his animal friends. Can you help Milly with her tasks and return Dapdap to his enclosure?

Components:
- 1 board
- 18 tiles (9x food, 3x flags, 3x paint bucket, 3x letters)
- 16 task tiles
- 1 wooden "Milly, the animal keeper" token
- 1 wooden "Dapdap, the penguin" token

Setup:
For the basic variant, 6 food tiles are removed from the game. 3 food tiles (showing 1 honeypot, 2 pieces of meet, 3 lettuce heads) and flag, paint bucket and letter tiles are put close to the corresponding corners of the board. The task tiles are randomised and stacked face-down. Dapdap is placed on the penguin enclosure.

Gameplay:
The start player takes the Milly token and puts it in front of him/herself to show it is his/her turn. He/she draws a task card. If it is a Milly card, he/she gets to help Milly. He/she looks which house (red, yellow or blue roof) Milly is running to and if she is delivering the mail, carrying the paint bucket, a flag, or if she is distributing food. He/she then looks for the correct tile at the board corners and puts it in the corresponding area on the board and gets to keep the task tile as a reward.
"Correct" means: matching colour for the paint buckets, matching shape for the flags (shape on the flag has to match the shape of the animal enclosure), matching number for the letters, and matching food (honey for the bear, meat for the lions, lettuce heads for the elephants).
If the tile drawn is a Dapdap card, the active player puts the Dapdap token to the next animal enclosure. Dapdap greets the animals in their language, so the player makes the corresponding sounds. For the correct greeting, they also get to keep the tile.
After completing the task, Milly is given to the next player, whose turn then starts. Incorrectly completed tasks are put at the bottom of the task tiles.

The game ends either when Dapdap has returned to his enclosure or when all items have been distributed (players decide which of the two they prefer). The game is intended to be played cooperatively, without deciding on a winner (but it can be played competitively by counting how many tiles each player has earned).

The advanced variant is played with all the food tiles and the players have to choose the tile showing the same number as food items as there are animals of that type, e.g. if Milly is going to feed the elephants, the player has to pick the food tile that shows three lettuce heads because there are three elephants.

name: Malifaux: Poltergeist
description:
Totem unit for the Neverborn, specific to Pandora.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki page:

Overview
The Poltergeist is a totem specific to Pandora that is often overlooked for other options. It does bring a few tricks to the table though that make it worth considering.

Mobility
With a movement that some would call on the lower side of average the Poltergeist can have a hard time keeping up with Pandora once she begins her train of effects. It should be able to keep up with most other models okay though, or at the very least have little issue getting into a useful position when thought out a turn or two ahead.

Offense
With no range attack some would quickly overlook the capabilities of this model, but it has a rather good severe damage for close combat. It's strength lies more so in the distraction abilities it brings to the table, however, in that it can make enemy models slow (and your own as well do not forget) and a few other shenanigans that suit a Pandora list quite well. Magical extension lets you use one of Pandora's spells another time each turn, and who doesn't want to cast Self-Loathing or Project Emotions another time?

Resilience
This model is short and so can hide easily. It has a high defense, but low wounds, so can die fairly easily if the opponent focuses on it. Spirit will help reduce the damage too, though, so the model can be quite survivable.

Magical Extension
Remember that any enemy model failing a WP duel within range of Pandora takes a wound, so casting spells that keep this going or give an opposing model negative flips while freeing up Pandora herself for other actions is always a plus.

Tips and Tricks
One trick with this totem is to use its Persistent Distraction spell while your own models are clustered near it to force your opponent to activate and use all of his models before you use any more of yours effectively out activating their entire crew with all of yours. This can be very situational and is probably not a good idea later in the game as you can leave yourself very exposed to attack, but can give you an early game advantage to seeing what your opponent has planned.

Using Magical Extension to cast Project Emotions and give enemy models a negative flip can help out several of the models often found in a Pandora crew.

name: Malifaux: Legion of Sorrow
description:
This box set expands the Malifaux universe by adding the Legion of Sorrow. The crew contains Pandora (leader), Baby Kade, Candy, and 3 Sorrows.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki page:

Pandora is the Master of Willpower (Wp) duels. She features powerful debuffs, crushing offensive abilities, and deceptive maneuverability, making her one of the more dangerous Masters in the game. But she is also known for her steep learning curve, taking many hard fought games to fully grasp her potential.

Pandora is focused around a web of effects consisting of The Box Opens, Emotional Trauma, Expose Fears, and Fading Memory. These four abilities form her core and are utilized by her spells and actions. The Box Opens allows her to affect just about any model in the game with her Wp-based effects while Emotional Trauma harms any enemy model failing a Wp duel near her. Expose Fears is her main defense against enemy models and forces any enemy model targeting her into a Wp -> Wp duel. Finally, Fading Memory adds a deceptive amount of maneuverability to an otherwise slow Master and, when paired with the other three abilities, provides her a unique defensive option of darting away from (or towards) an opponent trying to target her.

Pandora's starter box is about perfect. It gives you a nicely rounded list of 23ss, leaving you 2 more for your Soulstone Pool during the game, and has a mix of Wp based models and dual purpose models. It comes with Pandora, Baby Kade, Candy, and 3 Sorrows. If you're a beginning Pandora player, it is highly recommended you play with the box set as it is for several games, or until you get a good handle on Pandora's mechanics and practice using your Sorrows to their greatest effect.

name: Malifaux: Arachnid Swarm
description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

The Steampunk Arachnid Swarm is the primary workhorse for crews led by Ramos, but you can utilize them with any Arcanist crews, and even in crews led by C. Hoffman or Leveticus. This model is typically well worth the 9 SS cost, and overall has good survivability, a good attack, and consistent damage output.

Overall, the Arachnids are pretty straight forward, and are basic melee attack units.

On the other hand Scatter uses a Summon technique, so if you plan to do the Scatter action, always be sure to use 1 general AP for something else first, and use your (+2) Melee Master and probably Self Repair or Disruption Field as well. Then when you Scatter, if you activated Disruption Field, it will automatically pass onto each of your newly summoned individual Arachnids. When they come into play, since they are Summoned, they are treated as new models, each with their own activation, but they will be Slow during that turn which they were summoned. The Scatter action is also different from Swarm Together, in that the individual Arachnids do not activate immediately, as in the Swarm Together scenario.

Against models with high Df, as mentioned above, Latch On is typically a good approach. One thing that works well is to move a Swarm up to the opponent, as long as it's less than 4" total, attack twice with (+2) Melee Master, activate (0) Disruption Field, and then use the Swarm's last (1) to Scatter. Since you have to put the individual Arachnids in base contact with the Swarm, you should be able to place at least two of the new Arachnids in base contact with your target. Then, when those individual ones get to activate (thus, good to do this at the end of your turn, after your opponent has activated all their models, if possible), you start out with the one not in base contact to move into base contact and (0) Latch On. Then your two Arachnids in base contact can (0) Latch On and attack vs -4 and -6 Df. If you can manage to set this up where your Steamborg Executioner or another Arachnid Swarm still need to activate after all of this, then you should be able to really do some damage. This is one of the best ways to handle high Df opponents like Lilith, Perdita Ortega, or the Coryphee Duet (if you can get them to stand still, that is).

Lastly, the Overwhelm trigger, as mentioned above is one of the most dangerous things about the Arachnid Swarm, and it is worth learning how to utilize it well, both in the game itself, and as a psychological tactic. If your opponent knows that you have not yet activated a Swarm or two in range of some of his better pieces, he may be cautious about playing higher cards from his hand earlier in the turn, because he wants to keep those for cheating up his Df against the potential Swarm attacks. So there are some good mind-games that can be utilized with the Swarm.

name: Wonderland
description:
Text from the rulebook:
The characters in this attractive game for young people are taken from the famous “Alice in Wonderland,” and brightly illustrated in colors.

The card “ALICE” is the particular one which the players most desire to retain in their hands, as, after all the cards have been played, the player holding “Alice” WINS the Game.

There are duplicates in the pack of every card except “Alice.”
Shuffle the cards and deal, one at a time, to each player.
All cards in a player’s hand that will match, after being dealt, are thrown aside.

The dealer begins by drawing a card from the player at his right hand, the player drawn from holding the cards so that the dealer cannot see what he is drawing.

If the card drawn will pair with something in the dealer’s hand, he throws both aside; if not, he retains it.

Whether it pairs or not, it then becomes the turn of the player from whom the card was drawn to draw from the player at HIS right.

When a player entirely runs out of cards, he stops playing and the game continues without him.
The game thus proceeds, drawing and matching, until “Alice” alone is left.

The last player holding “Alice” WINS THE GAME.

name: Touhou Shisouroku: Rinnosuke Morichika Promo Card
description:
A promo card released for the Shrine Maiden version of Dominion.

This promo was sent to people who bought both the Extra arc box and the Imperishable Night box, and contained 10 cards of Rinnosuke and 1 divider (red back).

The card's effect is

+ 1 card

+1 action

+ 1 coin

Cost 8*
During your buy phase, the price of this card is reduced by 2 (to a minimum of 0) for every action card you have in your play area.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Video Game Theme

name: Kleine Helden 2 promo card "Der Auftrag"
description:
A promo card for Kleine Helden.

"Auftrag" is the German word for "mission". The card can be used as an mission for Kleine Helden 2.

name: Fortunes
description:
Fortunes is a trick taking tarot game where the Major Arcana can change the rules for a hand. Its based on a fantasy world where they literal gamble with their fates using this game. If you are losing a hand and you can't follow suit you could use a Major Arcana card to switch the hand from high to low and make your partner win the trick.

When the north and south players lead a trick the low card wins, and when the east or west players lead a trick the high card wins. Following suit is necessary and the Major Aracana cards switch high tricks to low ones or visa versa unless Major Arcana was what led the trick.

The team gets points for each trick they win and the team with the most points at the end of a hand wins that hand.

name: Malifaux: Silent One
description:
This expansion for Malifaux includes 1 Silent One ,Arcanist Minion specifically designed to work with Rasputina.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki site:

Silent Ones are the priestesses of the Cult of December. Upon learning that the Vessel of December was to be a woman the male priests (December Acolytes) turned on the priestesses, cut out and ate their tongues to prevent them speaking for December. Upon the arrival of Rasputina the Silent Ones attend her loyally and lend devastating magical assistance on the battlefield.

The Silent Ones are designed to work with Rasputina primarily, but may have some limited synergy with other Masters, they run 6 Soulstone cost.

Rasputina should not go to war without a Silent One, two are useful if you have the stones as they can buff each other. Rasputina will naturally benefit from the range boost in the initial turns off the game, but as the enemy gets closer the Silent One can offer a plethora of support abilities; healing, offensive casting and slowing the enemy down. All this and Rasputina can cast through them from a safe distance and with less of a Ca detriment than through, say, a Gamin.

Silent Ones have been described as mini-Raspys and should be treated as such. They are very good casters, but with low Df and Wd they can be defeated in melee in short order. Ranged strikes will have to contend with Bulletproof and ranged or melee Spells can be ignored with Counterspell. Remember that a lone Silent One can freeze your minion's heart, turn them into a statue and walk out of combat so if you go after them make sure that either they have already activated or that you can dispose of them in one activation.

name: Malifaux: Hoarcat Pride
description:
This expansion adds an Arcanist Minion to the Malifaux universe.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki site:

The Hoarcats are the cute and cuddly kitties of Malifaux that will rip your throat out. One isn't much of a problem, but the more of them there are the more trouble you are in.

The Hoarcat Pride's mobility is nothing to write home about, but they aren't bad either. They have a walk on the low side of average at 4, but their charge is slightly higher than most minions at 7. Their Pass Through ability also helps them to get around models trying to block a charge lanes.

What the Hoarcat pride lacks in Mobility it makes up for in Offense. They have an average Cb on their Claws, but their damage track is quite high for their Soulstone cost. Add to this their (+1) Melee Expert and they have a lot of opportunity to lay down the hurt. The one caveat is that their damage is based off of how many Wd they have left. So the more damage they take the less damage they can deal out.

You'll also want to save your high crows so that you can get their Rip Throat trigger. This will give an extra boost to damage against defenders without Armor.

The other Offensive ability they bring to the table is their Devour spell. This allows them to sacrifice a Ht 1 model. If you have more than one Hoarcat Pride within 3" you can benefit from their Voracious ability. This allows the them to double their Ca when casting Devour and allows them to cast it on Ht 2 models as well. Keep in mind though that the target of Devour has to be living, so this isn't going to work well against some crews.

Being a Beast, the Hoarcat Pride is going to get the most synergy out of working for Marcus. Pack Leader can help to get an alpha strike with the Hoarcat Pride's high damage. While Howl can boost the Hoarcat up to an impressive 8 Wp. Finally, Primal Flame can help to heal them up and keep their damage high.

Myranda has a few of synergies with the Hoarcat Pride. First off, like Marcus, Myranda can companion with other Beasts granting the potential for alpha strikes. Second, if she takes the form of the Hoarcat Pride with her Shapechange Spell it is enough to activate the original Hoarcat's Voracious ability. Thus giving the benefits of Voracious without have to actually hire two Prides. In the same vein Myranda can use her Animal Instincts Spell to cast Devour herself with her higher Ca. Finally, her Primal Flame Spell can help to give the Hoarcat Pride back those few Wds it needs in order to keep the damage high.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures

name: Mixed Hill
description:
Mixed Hill is a team board game of the roll-move-action type. Two players per team, they represent time traveling agents from the future racing against opposing agents to the top of the mystic hill where a reward awaits the most successful team.

On each turn the dice is rolled to move the active player and the action on the landed tile is then undertaken. These actions vary and most of them pitch players from different teams against each other. The winner of the action earns points so the winner is not just the first team to the top but the team with most points collected.

Due to easy and quick to grasp rules, the speed of the game, constant involvement in the action and a variety of tile actions, Mixed Hill appeals to non-gamers and gamers alike.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: March or Die: Rules for the French Foreign Legion
description:
From the Introduction

March or Die is a set of simple rules for the hard fought actions between the French Foreign Legion and the Arab Tribes of Morocco.

The game is designed so that all of the participants are on the same side (the Legion) whilst the marauding Arabs are controlled by dice-driven action tables in the rules. The game can be played solo, with a group of friends or as a public participation game at any of the numerous wargames shows.

The rules themselves are not designed for the serious wargamer, but for those of us whose main aim in wargaming is to enjoy the game no matter the result.

The idea for March or Die has been greatly inspired by that most enjoyable game Pony Wars or 'B' Troop Aint Coming Back.

name: Sudan Campaign Wargame
description:
A rule book for map & board-campaign wargame. The game may be used to establish a tactical confrontation for a miniature table top battle.

From the Introduction

The game is designed for Wargamers either as a "board game" or as an adjunct to a tabletop Battlegame using miniature figures and scenery on a 5' x 5' or larger table.

As a BOARD GAME, a small campaign can be played using MAPS, ROSTERS and MARKERS supplied. A complete campaign can be played in two or three hours. In such a game, there is a great deal of "the fog of war", grand tactical maneuvering, scouting, and simulated conflict between forces, and the issuing of basic pre-commands.

As an adjunct or OVERLAY to a miniature wargame, the game still uses MAPS and FORCE MARKERS, but also sets up circumstances for a Sudan era (1880's thru 1890's) tabletop battlegame using miniature figures. Often during such a campaign there will be two or three separate table top battles and sometimes reinforcements can be brought in. The game also has rules for combat between gunboats and feluccas.

The rules have been devised for straight forward and fast play with minimal referencing to tables, and uses ten-sided (percentile) dice for moving, combat and morale resolution.

The game includes copiable maps, roster sheets and markers (counters) that the player needs to cut-out and mount themselves to play the MAP game.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Square Grid

name: Karnag: The Congregations ‚Äì Kaoterio√π
description:
Kaoterioù is an additional congregation — a single card — for use in Karnag: The Congregations. It was a "goodie" distributed with the first issue of Plato Worldwide.

It was also included as a goodie in Plato-Magazine number 52 (in French).

The player who is a member of this congregation receives 1 VP / level every time they progress at least three levels all at once in the same knowledge track (by any means: action, cauldron, combined with cards or not, etc.)
mechanics: Action Points, Enclosure, Modular Board, Variable Phase Order, Worker Placement

name: Fantastic Football
description:
The Fast Action Soccer Card Game!

Players control the ball by playing pass, tackle, shoot, save and other cards to win the game before the cards run out.
