Jumping over other pieces or moving to an already-occupied square is not allowed.

Goal
The player who succeeds in placing 3 respective (single) pieces or set of pieces in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal row wins the game.

The player loses when he/she cannot move his/her piece(s).

The player who places 4 respective pieces or combination of pieces in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal row loses the game.(This rarely happens.)

name: Town Center: Manhattan
description:
The main item in Town Center: Manhattan is a T-shirt printed with a Town Center game board that's been designed for solitaire play. The game board in question features Manhattan's Central Park and surrounding blocks, and if multiple people own the shirt and components, then presumably they could play competitively.

Town Center: Manhattan was first offered as a funding perk for the Indiegogo campaign for the 3rd edition of Town Center It was also included in the Town Center (Fourth Edition), funded via Kickstarter.
categories: Abstract Strategy, City Building, Expansion for Base-game

name: Cooking Party Cards
description:
Cooking Party Cards is a light social game for food lovers, child cooks, aspiring chefs, and fans of kitchen disasters.

Players will be creating unique dishes, sitting in judgment on your fellow players, and maybe even preparing the winning meals to eat.

In each round one player will be the judge. When playing as a judge, a player chooses one "Assignment card" and reads the cooking assignment to the other players, who take on the role of "Chefs".

When playing as a Chef, a player follows any special rules of the assignment to assemble a hand of "Ingredient" cards and then uses these cards to invent a food dish to present to the judge.

Some example assignments:
"Chef's Choice": Chefs prepare a single dish of their choice. Judge deals each Chef 7 cards; they may trade in up to 3; they must use at least 4.
"Sabotage": Judge deals each chef 7 cards and instructs each Chef to pass one card to the player clockwise. Chefs must use the card passed to them in their final dish. After exchanging cards with their neighbors, Chefs may trade in up to 3 and must use at least 4.
"Special Ingredient": Judge chooses a Special Ingredient of their choice from the Ingredient deck and places it face up on the table, and deals each Chef 7 cards; they may trade in up to 3; they must use at least 3, in addition to the Special Ingredient.
"Distasteful Dish": Judge deal each Chef 7 cards; they may trade in up to 3; they must use exactly 4 cards to create the worst tasting dish they can think of.

After the Chefs create their dishes, they take turn describing them to the judge, who chooses how to divide up points to the chefs based on the quality of their creations. The role of judge then rotates for the next round.

After all players have had a chance to play the role of judge, scores from each round are tallied up; the winner is the player with the most total points over all rounds.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Quadrant 13: Rules for Company Size Actions in a Science Fiction Universe
description:
From publisher's site:
Quadrant 13 (Q13) is a company-sized game covering science fiction warfare aimed primarily at using 6-15mm figures. It uses the same basic mechanics as I Ain’t Been Shot, Mum! and/or Charlie Don’t Surf, but is as different in flavour from them as they are from each other. It is a stand-alone game: no other rulebooks or supplements are necessary to play.

The rules are completely generic, allowing players to use them to play any sci-fi conflict that they choose: whether based on background from another system, background from a film or book, background from a range of figures, or even a background that they have made up themselves. It also allows gamers to play the type of science fiction game that they want to play: ‘hard’ sci fi, where realism is the key; space opera style games which run almost like a film; battles featuring a small number of super-tough figures against a large number of not-so-tough opponents…you name it, you can play it.

Q13 is written by Robert Avery, author of eight scenario books for I Ain’t Been Shot, Mum!, all of which are also available from theTooFatLardies.

name: Crosscontrol
description:
Abstract game for two players. Best played on a Reversi board, can be extended over a 19x19 Goban.
rules:
1) players place alternately one piece on the board
2) pieces on the board influence their cell and all the cells along horizontal, vertical and diagonal lines, up to the first occupied cell included.
3) a player can occupy a cell if the number of pieces of him influencing that cell is equal or higher than that of the opponent; if the cell is empty, that player occupies it with one of his pieces, if it's occupied by the opponent, the player will change that piece with one of his pieces.
4) when a player has no more available moves, he must pass the turn to his opponent
5) game is over when both player have no more moves
6) the winner is the player with the higher number of pieces on the board when the game is over

A "pie rule" is recommender for the opening (first player has a clear advantage); otherwise, a compensation (like Komi in Go) should be used (TBD)

name: Royal Strawberries
description:
Summer is here, which -- for the kingdoms of Feorhyrna -- means it's time to raid the strawberry patch! In all the world, no item is more sought after than the Feorhyrnan strawberry: wars have been waged and kingdoms have been lost all in an effort to possess its mysterious, magical fruit.

But that was last year (things are more civilized now); instead of war, the kingdoms of Feorhyrna have agreed to send eight champions to the royal strawberry patch to collect this year's harvest. It's first-come-first-serve, though, and there are no rules about how to divvy up the fruit...but they'll work on that next year. In the meantime, it's time to bust some skulls and grab some strawberries!

Royal Strawberries is a whimsical game of tactics and strategy in which teams of fabulous characters navigate a garden maze and fight for the fabled fruit of Feorhyrna. When the last strawberry is plucked (or the Royal Bazaar is exhausted), the game ends and each kingdom tallies up its victory points (from strawberries and other bonuses): the kingdom with the most points wins!
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Elemental Strife
description:
Elemental Strife is a chess style semi abstract game for two players that take turns playing on a board of 10 by 10 squares, 32 of which are randomly covered up with one of the elements, being 8 of each type, which configures a different scenario every encounter.

Prior to start each player chooses one of the elements to play with: earth, water, fire and air. Having each faction its own characteristics. For example: air elementals are faster, and can pass through other element spaces, while earth elementals are very hard to capture.

Each team has 15 pieces in four levels, higher level (4) are stronger and dangerous but have less movement capability. Each player starts with 5 of those elementals, but can create new ones during the course of the game.

name: Galtoni
description:
Your goal in Galtoni is to place four balls of your color in a straight line, whether diagonal or orthogonal.

Unlike in other games with this concept, this game has a randomizing element in that the board resembles a Galton Board. Players take turns inserting a ball in one of the openings at the top of the slanted board. As the ball rolls down the board, it hits a series of pegs that deflect it and bounce it around before it lands in one of seven slots at the bottom of the board.

You can play with each player dropping only balls of their own color, or you can have players draw a ball at random from a bag, thereby possibly forcing them to figure out where best to drop a ball of an opponent's color. Two neutral balls are included, and these count toward each player's line.

name: Hexa Sea
description:
Welcome to the Hexa Sea, General. This land is vital to our Nation. We must hold it at any cost, and remove the enemy's presence. Set a hold in the land of the Hexa Sea, bring forth our Army, and strike deep at the enemy headquarters. Win for us.

Hexa Sea is an abstract, terrain control wargame played on a modular map that changes every new game. You set hold on the map with your Headquarters, build new units and fight your opponent off the map.

The board is comprised of sea tiles and land pieces called Hexas. These Hexas are arranged over the board forming islands with land tiles. Controlling different numbers of Hexas allow the player to build different units, that interact between themselves in different ways. The goal of the game is to capture the Soldier controlling your opponent's Headquarters.

3rd Best Overall Game, 3rd Best Art/Graphic Design, 2nd Best New Mechanic and 2nd Best Wargame at the 2013 Two-Player PnP Game Design Contest

name: FumezZif!
description:
A simple and fast deduction game.

Fumezzif! was the winning print&play game of the Modena municipal administration contest for Play - Il Festival Del Gioco 2013 gaming event.

Each player, following the comic strip drawn on the board, must try to guess at what point is the marker of the opponent.
If he wins gets a bonus, if loses gets a penalty.
The player who, at the end of comic strip, has the marker on the higher score wins.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Deduction, Print & Play
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Memory, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Arras 1940
description:
Probably the most important battle of the french campaign in 1940. Attack of the british infantry and armored troops could cut down spearhead of the german offensive. Personal intervention of the gen. Erwin Rommel saved Germans from disaster.
"Arras 1940" has two scenarios, historical and optional, that add French Armored Division as main offensive force of the allies.
Game was added to the 2nd issue of "Taktyka and Strategia" magazine. It uses mechanic titled "B35", used for battles fought in 1943-1945 at the western front. Full rules were published years after in the game "Bitwy Drugiej Wojny ≈öwiatowej".

name: Compass 1940
description:
Operation Compass was a British counter offensive against the Italians in December 1940. After Grazziani's attack in September, British army performed a counterstike that totally destoyed most of the Italian forces in Libya.

The game contains three scenarios - "Grazziani's Attack", "Operation Compass" and "Selby Corps". It uses same rules as "El-Alamein 1942".

It was included in Taktyka i Strategia issue 19.

name: Ancona
description:
The Battle of Ancona (Italy - 16th June-18th July 1944) was one of the last battles fought by the Polish Forces during the World War II Italian Campaign. Ancona was an important seaport in the eastern Italy and capturing it could shorten allies lines of communication. Ancona was captured at 18th July by the Polish II Corps.

"Ancona" was attached to the issue #8 of the "Dragon Hobby" magazine and uses the rules of "Bitwy Drugiej Wojny ≈öwiatowej" system (called B-35 for short).

name: Raszyn 1809
description:
The Battle of Raszyn was fought on 19 April 1809 between armies of the Austrian Empire under Archduke Ferdinand Karl Joseph and the Duchy of Warsaw under Prince Józef Antoni Poniatowski.

Austrian armies, part of the Fifth Coalition, invaded Duchy of Warsaw in April 1809. In the battle of Raszyn polish army managed to stop them. It was major victory for a newborn polish army and one of the most important battles for polish people in XIX century.

Game is typica hex and counter wargame. It uses the rule of "Napoleon" system, made for the XIX century battles. "Raszyn 1809" was attachted to the 9th issue of the "Dragon Hobby" magazine.

name: Existenz: On the Ruins of Chaos ‚Äì Energy Sublimation Apparatus Promo
description: This promo can be redeemed by submitting the voucher found in each purchased copy of Existenz: On the Ruins of Chaos.
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement

name: The National Hunt Sport of Kings: The Hurdlers
description: An expansion of Sport of Kings. This one includes many new horses that you can train and race. Basic and campaign game rules are provided. The basic rules expand the basic game to include hurdles.
categories: Animals, Expansion for Base-game, Racing, Sports

name: The Solo Wargaming Guide
description:
Can't find a tabletop wargame opponent?

This easily-readable guide provides the tools needed to undertake tabletop wargame campaigns without the need for other players. The guidelines presented within are designed to supplement your favorite wargaming rules set (not included). They can be bent or twisted, even broken and reformed, to suit a wargamer's needs. Novices and veterans alike can employ these ideas and innovations to further the thrill of pitting army against army without the need for another player. Features methodologies for campaigns (mobilization, weather, logistics, morale, alliances, revolts, sieges, and mutinies), sea campaigns, integrating fantasy, tactical actions (terrain, weather, commander's competency, concealment, ambushes, and minefields), and air warfare.

name: Yafra 1942/1945
description:
Game simulates fictional battles at western Pacific, fought between Japanese and American forces at the island Yafra. It was first part of the mini series for "Bitwy drugiej wojny ≈õwiatowej" system about battles at Pacific during II World War.

"Yafra 1942/1945" was publish in the 2nd issue of "Dragon Strateg" magazine and contained two scenarios - Japanese landing at August 1942 and Americana attack at February 1945.

Island itself and battles fought on it are fictional, but were based upn real fights at Philipines or Iwo Jima. There were also some new rules to the "Bitwy drugiej wojny ≈õwiatowej" system, made for battles at Pacific, including Kamikaze units, guerilla and caves.

name: Gold Strike
description:
The Board Game of "Gold Strike" relives the craze of the "GOLD RUSH DAYS." The game follows closely the exciting pattern of activities connected with the quest for gold and lives again the thrills and disappointments of successes and failures. Names, locations, and events, where practical, are historically accurate! The object of the game is to rush into the gold fields, stake as many claims as possible and obtain the available gold. Many hazards will be found that challenge the daring of the individual and adds excitement and interest to the game!
Components:game instructions, 4 wooden game pieces, 1 wooden dice, 1 game board, travel cards, pawn tickets, mineral claim cards, gold strike cards, store cards, burro cards.

name: Surfboard
description:
"Surfboard" Australian Board Game from the early-to-mid 1960s, made by John Sands during the heyday era of Surfing. Must-have item for all surf collectors.
Object: To take a team of 2 surf board riders from the start at the beach, around the buoy to the Finish at the clubhouse.
Beside the Playing Board, there are 25 Action Cards, 8 Surfies (4 colours X 2 Surfies each), and 4 Round Playing Balls/Marbles of the same 4 colours. The Rules of the Game are printed on the inside of the Box.

name: Spout
description:
Spout is a mini-version of Upper Hand played on the Shibumi set. Each player starts with 15 balls, and the board starts empty. Players take turns adding a ball of their color to any board hole or 2x2 platform. If the move completes a 2x2 platform containing at least three friendly balls, then the player places another ball on the platform; if that move completes another 2x2 platform containing at least three friendly balls, then the player places another ball on it, and so on. It is possible for a single ball placement to complete multiple friendly-majority platforms, in which case they are each completed with a friendly ball.

A player wins if it's their turn to move and they have no balls remaining. This can occur mid-move when a majority 2x2 platform is completed or at the start of the player's next turn.

Spout is similar to Upper Hand except that a 4x4 board is used, no "wild" ball is needed for the opening move, and there's a next-turn delay on the winning condition (which avoids a significant first player advantage).

For the three-player version of Spout, each player starts with ten balls and only two friendly balls are required to own a 2x2 platform.

name: Tantek 1942/45
description:
Game simulates fictional battles at western Pacific, fought between Japanese and American forces at the Tantek archipelago. It was second part (first was "Yafra 1942/45") of the mini series for "Bitwy drugiej wojny ≈õwiatowej" system about battles at Pacific during II World War.

"Tantek 1942/1945" was publish in the 4nd issue of "Dragon Hobby" magazine and contained two scenarios - Japanese landing at July 1942 and Americana attack at March 1945.

name: Treasure of the Golden Fortress
description:
In this exciting game of swashbuckling piracy, each player controls a band of swarthy pirates raiding a heavily fortified island. Players must compete against one another as well as against the island itself, which is firing wildly.

Each player chooses one of the eight different Ships to command, which indicates the Crew, Artillery, Ammunition, Speed, and Hull. Players can board enemy pirate ships, fire cannons, and fight the winds as they maneuver their ships around the island.

Players win only after the island's defense have been destroyed and each other player has been eliminated, either through destroying the ship or killing the entire crew.
categories: Adventure, Fighting, Nautical, Pirates, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Champions of the Colosseum
description:
In Champions of the Colosseum, each player acts as a lanista, or manager of a gladiatorial school, during Ancient Rome. As such, each lanista can buy, sell, or trade 34 different types of gladiators and beasts to fight in the arena.

Lanistas are able to place wagers on their fights, gain crowd favor, train gladiators, and create Champions in an effort to gain reputation. A lanista wins the game when his or her Champion wins a final battle in the Colosseum for all to see!

Each combatant has unique stats and abilities, which alter the random dice rolling of each gladiatorial battle.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Dice, Fighting, Print & Play
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Call This A Ruddy Picnic?: An East Africa Scenario Supplement
description: A classic quote from a British trooper in East Africa as he examined his tinned “picnic ham” ration pack. And that's not the only thing that's classic about this excellent, ground-breaking scenario supplement covering the campaign in East Africa between June of 1940 and November of 1941. With twenty-three scenarios and bags of historical background they also contain a campaign system that can be used with Bag the Hun to refight the campaign in the air
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Cymru Am Byth: The Welsh Guards at War 1939-45
description: A first for IABSM, a supplement covering one Regiment through all its major battles of the war. With sixteen company-level scenarios designed for “I Ain’t Been Shot, Mum!” but easily adaptable to other systems, this covers actions from France in 1940, Tunisia 1943, Italy and northern Europe in 1944 and '45. It also presents a unique campaign system for the actions around the Albert Canal bridgehead in Belgium in 1944 when the Welsh Guards took on the Herman Goring Division.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: With Fire and Sword: Skirmishes and Battles in South Carolina June to August 1780
description:
With Fire and Sword is a supplement for Sharp Practice covering the activities in South Carolina between June and August 1780, a critical time for the American Revolution in the south after the fall of Charleston.

The skirmishes and small battles that affected the north of the State were to decide whether the Revolution in the South continued, and were to gaina significance way beyond their actual size.

Chris Stoesen of Georgia has carefully pieced together the events during this period of intense and often vicious warfare and created twenty-four scenarios for Sharp Practice that will provide the gamer with a selection of scenarios, from a dozen or so men a side up to over 100 figures each covering milita, provincial and regular troops. Even Banastre Tarleton gets to make an appearance.
categories: American Revolutionary War, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame

name: Laughing Stock
description: Laughing Stock is a light, family dice game that can be taught in less than 5 minutes and can be enjoyed by gamers as young as eight years old. Inspired by “Texas Hold Em”, players take turns rolling dice to try and score sets of animal tiles from the center of the table. The player with the best “hand” gets to add the matching animals to their collection. But watch out for the hyenas! These pranksters will limit what sets you can make and eventually end the game! At the end of the game, the winner is the player with the most majorities of each of the six types of animals.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: WOW: World of Words
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Unlike other word games, in WOW: World of Words there's no waiting for turns. When the timer starts, all players make as many words as they can in just one minute. Turn over a blue card for the first letter and turn over a red card for the last letter. Players score points for each unique word of five or more letters, with bonus points for longer words. Special cards add exciting twists.

'Report from "World of Words" annual convention:'
I have news that I hope you'll be happy about. Our Games Gang play-tested 12 new word games. WOW was undoubtedly the simplest of the 12 games we played, and this is a tough crowd. But we all loved playing it. Sometimes simpler is better, especially in a situation like Words Weekend when getting up and running on a new game is so great. Gloria totally concurs, too. We loved the elegance and purity of the game -- nothing is extraneous or fussy. I think this may be the first time we have ever played a card game at Mohonk.

name: The Crazy War
description:
The Crazy War is a game for two players only.

The history is going wrong! Assassins have to kill the robots; janissaries are fighting against scientists; arrows versus missiles. It seems normal, but it is middle ages!

Control your armies, make your own plan, and lead your troops to victory!

Players have to control their troops and occupy 8 spaces on the game board to win. There are variants of cards like troop cards, building cards, and plan cards. You have to pay for the cards to put(launch) them. Also, you have to choose the best position on the 3×4 game board to put your cards to block your opponent. Think about your plans, it’s Crazy War!

The game contains:
·150 cards
·some woden cubes (damage marker)
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Eureka City
description:
Eureka City is a dice-and-card city construction game. Players all have a hand of cards and a common pool. They take turns setting up a "building plan" for their city by playing a series of cards that represent buildings, then rolling a number of dice and distributing them on the cards they have played. Each building completed gains the player some special effect. Buildings can be taken over by opponents unless you're careful. Once a player has five buildings of the same color, he is entitled to build a monument of that color, which also grants him some special effect.

Once all available monuments have been built, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

name: Noah's Order
description:
Noah's Order is a simple indie card game. Players all have a set of ten animals that are supposed to board Noah's Ark. There are also neutral animals with no owner.

Each round, players play a number of their animals face down. All animals are then revealed, and the round rule is revealed determining in which order the animals will line up. The first six animals enter the Ark, gaining points for their respective owner. The quirky scoring mechanism is that the neutral animals are scored by the player who has the most distance between his first and his last animals in the queue; hence the game is about guessing what the next sorting rule will be, combined with good planning and out-thinking the other players.

name: Juhla Alias
description:
Anniversary edition of Alias

Alias consists of many cards, each card has 6 words written on it. Each word has a number, from 1 to 6. Words are various - from very easy to very hard. Some are made of several words defining one thing (example: "Silver Medal"). There is also a board with tiles. Each tile is marked with number from 1 to 6.

Alias is played in teams, usually in teams of 2, but more people are also allowed. The "explainer" must change every turn. Each team gets a figure representing them on the board. Their goal is to get through the board. Each time a figure stops one team member must take cards from the pack (not showing it to the other team member(s)) and explain the words on every card that have the same number as the space their figure landed on. The hourglass (also included) is set just before the team member starts explaining the word. (Looking at the first card and thinking about how to explain the word before the time is set is allowed.) The Player must get the other team member to say the word that is written on card by using sentences to describe the word. For example, if the word is "Silver Medal", a player can say "something that a sportsman wins at the Olympic games". But if other team member says just "Medal", it isn't correct. Then the first player must further define what the hint might be. Second player can answer as often as he/she wants until the time runs out. If time runs out or first player accidentally uses the word which is written in card, the team loses a turn. Variations: opposites and/or foreign words are allowed.
mechanics: Acting, Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Wasserball
description:
Each player rolls the die - ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on the cover backside (e.g. back to field 8, pass your turn, roll the dice one more time...).
Objective: Be the first moving up to field 50.
Published before WWII.

name: Nearspace
description:
Near Space is a strategic 4X war game that turns the dice you own into a fleet of ships to conquer the universe. In the game, two fledgling empires stare across the void at one another.

The Terran Alliance explores space eager for new frontiers and resources to exploit. They are a cantankerous collection of conflicting factions united only in their refusal to accept any limitation to their individual ambitions. They are at their strongest — and happiest — when challenged.

The Alpha Centauri Regime advances into space to meet the alien threat and eliminate it. They are a single people united under a single banner. The State gives every citizen a purpose, and every citizen gives their all to the State. Anything less is unacceptable.

Now aware of the existence of the other, both sides advance eagerly for the conflict to come. The one thing they share is an appetite for war. Seize the stars!

In game terms, players take on the roles of stellar empires fighting for survival and supremacy amongst the blackness of space. The field of cards between the home worlds of the opposing forces defines Nearspace and the resources that both players have to work with. As players explore their surroundings, each card reveals new threats to overcome and new resources to capture. The war ships that the two opponents bring to battle are dice. Any polyhedral die works as a ship for Near Space. The number of facets on a die are the strength of its armaments and defenses. The more facets, the more powerful the ship and consequently the more costly to field. Polyhedral dice come in a multitude of colors that are used to define the job of a ship and the design specifications involved. Four-sided fighters race forward in the vanguard while d10 battleships bring their firepower to bear at a more ominous pace. Each fleet must explore uncharted space, control colony worlds, pacify unaligned forces, and prepare to battle the ever-advancing enemy!

name: A Monstrous Fuss: The Battle of Wilson's Creek, August 10, 1861
description:
“Great stir in camp this evening. General Lyon has issued an order that this night shall decide the fate of Southern Missouri…We are going to march on them tonight.”
--August 9th, 1861 Diary entry by William Branson, Iowan of the Muscatine Volunteer Infantry.

“I will gladly give up my life for victory.”
--General Nathaniel Lyon, around 1:00 AM, August 10th, 1861.

A Monstrous Fuss is a simulation of the battle fought on August 10th, 1861 at Wilson’s Creek between the Union Army under General Nathaniel Lyon and the Confederate forces led by Generals Benjamin Mcculloch and Sterling Price. The Union force, badly outnumbered, launched a bold attack that caught the Rebels still encamped. Both sides armies’ were made up of militia and volunteers who were in combat for the first time. The intensity and casualties sustained in this day’s battle surprised many of the officers and further reinforced that this Civil War would not be settled quickly or cheaply. Can you do better?

Terrain scale is about 250 yards per hex, while the infantry and cavalry units are mostly regiments, artillery units are batteries of 4-6 guns. Each turn is about 30 minutes. Each strength point represents 250 men.

name: M√°s-Menos
description:
Drawing from Michael Waitsman's Proteus rather than from Nomic-related card games, Más-Menos is a trick-taking game for two players and a 32-card deck constructed around two variable winning conditions: one applied to single tricks and another applied to the whole game. These conditions will change during play as tricks are won by cards of different suits.

Both players start out with a hand of 16 cards - after discarding three each they must determine the winning conditions that will apply from the first trick on. After that tricks are played; the suit of the winning card of each trick will switch one of the two currently valid conditions - red cards determine if highest or lowest wins a trick, black cards determine if more or less tricks win a game.

name: Reword
description: There are 52 cards with different letters on either side, 4 blank cards, and a tray with 5 bins for cards. The cards are dealt evenly, players take turns placing letters in the trays until the last one is full -- making a valid word. Then there are no turns: players just play one of their cards to the middle, replacing a letter with another letter to make another valid word. When a player plays all his cards the round stops and he scores 1 point for each other card unplayed by the others. The first to 25 points wins.

name: Deer Season
description:
This is a Deer Hunting Game tested and approved by Deer Hunters.
This game captures the essence of the hunt. Nearly every element of sitting in your tree stand waiting for the big buck to appear is woven into the fabric of this wonderful game. Players pick cards from 4 piles representing different locations in the woods, these cards include the deer, its orientation to the hunter and the range. When a player has all three he can shoot if he has the available tags. The deer are constantly moving and players need to make decisions about using an extra shot, buying an extra deer tag, or a scope.
Hunters can fall asleep, spook deer, and track blood trails if not a clean shot. Not only is it fun for hunters, but non hunters love it too. The player with the most weight wins. There is also two score modifiers, the Deer Magnet razz given to a player who misses his shot, and the Warden who visits once per game.
There is also a legendary King (ghost) Buck that is so elusive the game provides a hall of fame certificate to record any hunter who manages to bag this enormous buck!
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Simulation, Turn Order: Time Track

name: BattleTech: Technical Readout ‚Äì 3145
description:
(Description from game publisher)

The great experiment that was the Republic of the Sphere has failed. Withdrawn behind the Fortress walls, the once-great power has become a silent, opaque remnant of its former glory. Without its influence, old hatreds have risen anew. As war once more rages across the Inner Sphere, new equipment strides across ancient battlefields. Technology, once stagnated by trade restrictions and peace treaties, now surges forward again, testing these new machines in the fierce crucible of war.

Technical Readout: 3145 introduces the latest wave of new battle armor, vehicle, ‘Mech, and aerospace units appearing in the Republic Armed Forces and across the Inner Sphere in the Dark Age era. Featuring new equipment described in Era Report: 3145 and Field Manual: 3145, this book brings players an update on the advancing technologies used in the battlefields of the thirty-second century.
categories: Book, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: "21" Lawn Dice
description: The game includes 8 giant plastic dice. Each team takes 4 of these dice and rolls them into targets. Any dice that land inside the rings score the numbers shown on top. Be the first team to score 21 and win.

name: Ave Caesar, morituri te salutant
description:
Meaning - "Hail Caesar, those who are about to die salute you"

Ave Caesar, morituri te salutant is a game of Gladiator combat in a Roman Gladiator arena. It has 1 to 4 combatants "Gladiators", plus Beasts, and Slaves!
The mechanics are slightly similar to Combat in the Lists with a new hex tile game board for the arena, 7 direction movement, new character sheets with abilities, new weapons and armor, beasts; such as lions and bears, slaves "non-trained" combatants, new tactics, and all new images and graphics for cards and components.

Each Gladiator has nine equipment counter locations on his reference card:

Head
Left shoulder
Right shoulder
Chest
Groin
Right hand
Left hand
Right leg
Left leg

These [9] locations can hold [9] different pieces of equipment which can be picked up before the match.

These new counters make up part of the new mechanics of the game where the equipment and weapons are represented by counters and cards! The counters fit into specific locations on the player’s reference cards and are distributed before the match through a process where each Gladiator takes turns picking a certain number of equipment pieces from an rack. This process can leave the Gladiators with a mix-match of different types of equipment and weapons but also make for a different game each time its played.

Each equipment counter is also represented by a Equipment Defense point card, which is used to keep track of the amount of damage a piece of equipment takes during a combat session. This new system makes up the other part of the new mechanics for Ave Caesar... Each piece of equipment depending on its type will use up to three different D6 die to help record the amount of damage that piece of equipment can take before it becomes useless. Once the piece of equipment take its max damage allotment, it no longer prevents damage from hitting the player.

Once equipped, the Gladiators take turns moving, fighting, repositioning, devising tactics and strategies to maneuver into position for the best attack and defense. If a Gladiator is killed all his equipment “counters” are placed on top of his player piece and are available to any of the combatants in the arena!

Each weapon and piece of equipment has a card explaining the attack and defense characteristics. Attach and Defense cards are used for combat to help devise a tactical strategy against other players.

This game will consist of the following components:
A combat arena
Gladiator player reference cards
Weapon cards
Equipment Defense point cards
Animal cards
Slave cards
Attack cards
Defense cards
Specialty type cards for combat and defense - Attack and Defense styles
Player game board pieces
Animal game board pieces
Slave game board pieces
Movement cards
etc...
And a new rules book
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Surf Trip: The Board Game
description:
Four surfers travel the world to see who can be the first to get $500 and 3 sponsors.

Players roll to move around the board, each space giving or taking cash or movement bonuses. Some spaces are surf contests which allow all surfs to surf against each other to win cash prizes and sponsors. Surfers flip cards which are their moves that provide points. A surfer can stop when he chooses, wipes out or the wave closes out. If he wiped out he gets no points, otherwise the points on the cards are summed.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Spare Parts: The Game of Undead Army Building
description:
In Spare Parts, players take on the role of mad scientists in the tradition of Dr. Frankenstein, racing to reanimate an army of undead creations and conqueror the world. The player with the most diabolical laugh gets to be the first to raid graveyards with the help of Igor and collect Spare Parts such as brains, lungs, and hearts. This loose collection of organs is brought back to the players lab where, with the help of a little electricity, they attempt to reanimate the undead creations currently on their lab tables. As zombies are completed their uniquely engineered characteristics can be used to interfere with the competition, or speed up your race to victory.

There are 11 different types of zombies each of which has an appropriate and unique cost to go with their ability. Lawyer zombies for instance only need lungs and brains- after all they only need to think and talk. The undead's special abilities are designed to keep competition close and give everyone a chance at victory- a careful mix of luck and strategy. The first player to amass an army of 6 undead creations wins the game and has permission to laugh and cackle manically for as long as they are able.

Players start the game with hand of five spare parts and two zombies recipes. At the beginning of each turn players draw two spare parts cards, and bring in fresh corpses to fill any empty lab tables. Players then play spare parts from their hand to match the costs of zombies they are building. Players can trade spare parts with other players on their turn to try to get the parts they need. When a zombie is completed it's special ability triggers, and it goes into the player's Army Pile. At the end of your turn you discard until your under your maximum had size. Play continues until a player has amassed an army of six zombies.

name: Killer Queen
description:
User summary:

A quirky Japanese indie card game with a dark theme: Players are brain-programmed killer machines, and try to win the game by either become the perfect soldier (the Killer Queen) or get rid of their psychological traumas. Or at least have as few as possible.

The deck consists of 24 cards numbered 1–7; players are dealt 3 cards. Each turn starts with that one or several cards are sent to the next player, and then players play one card each. Players who play a card that are not yet in the common pool, place their played card in the common pool. But if there already is a card of that number in the common pool, it's placed in the player's "point" area.
If a player manages to get a total of 12 in his point area, he wins, but the road there is paved with the other players getting into your way, and seven different weird special effects, one of which flips the whole deck face up.

name: Dungeonling: Battle
description:
Play as a fearsome Dungeon Lord, as you contest against your opponent for spoils. Send your Dungeonling Minions to attack and defend, all the while casting powerful, game-changing spells in an epic battle for victory!

Dungeonling:Battle is a dueling card game in a similar style like Magic:tG, but with its own unique elements. Player must gather resources (the Spoils), and play Minion and Spells cards against each other. However, instead of custom deck, player use a shared deck, and the Spoils can be taken and looted away by attacks. And with the 3-Actions per Turn system, Players also have much more freedom in choosing what strategy to take, and not simply restricted by phases. This creates a more dynamic playing field, where a great hand could win you a comeback and net you the victory.

Easy to learn, but with deep strategy. It’s a great game for both young and casual gamer, as well as card game veteran alike. It's Time to Battle!
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Alien Invasion
description:
Based on the introduction from the rules

A skirmish level miniatures game designed to be played by four to six players in about an hour and a half. Each player will control a competing faction with personal victory conditions to achieve based on the scenario chosen. Not all victory conditions are mutually exclusive so alliances and diplomacy have their place.

The game is ostensibly set in a fictional present day but this is not a requirement. Many of the factions are drawn from popular culture and new factions can be added very easily simply by quantifying a small number of variables. The game requires minimal measuring, no charts and a lot of six sided dice. The rules will be memorised by a player by their second action and everyone can then oncentrate on having

Factions included in the rules are;

UNIT
The Doctor
Daleks
Men in Black
Spugs


Additional Factions are avaliable on auther website, including;

Cybermen
Invaders from Mars
Shado (UFO)
Shadow Men
Non Combatants
Gangstaz
Grell
Zombies
Alien Zombies
Little Green Men


The rules are avaliable for free from authers website'
categories: Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: AirWar: C21 bomber annex
description:
An expansion data annex for the core game "AirWar:C21" by Wessex Games. This includes some typical bombers seen in the jet age such as the Soviet Badger or Bear bombers, the UK V bomber force and Chinese bombers.

You need the core rules to use this.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: High Seas: The Card Game
description:
Many countries are fighting for rule of the Caribbean. Your king has equipped you with a flagship to take control of the High Seas. In a race against the other players to explore and fortify the Caribbean, the one who can assemble the largest armada will secure ultimate control.

This is a card game that is easy to learn, quick to play, and each game is different with 85 unique crew and ports, plus a variety of resources and ships.

Throughout the game, you will search for and collect resources, maps, ship plans, and crew references. You will use these to visit exotic ports, construct forts for permanent bonuses, expand your fleet with various ships, and recruit a powerful crew.

The first one to survive the battles and build the largest armada wins!

The game is played exclusively through actions listed on cards in your 'Armada' (cards in play on the table), and a few base actions which are available to every player. You begin the game with two cards in your Armada (3 in the shorter game), which contain basic actions, such as drawing a new card to your hand. Each player takes as many actions as they would like, and then announces their turn is over, beginning the next player's turn.

Actions are divided into two types based on how often you may use them: one time per turn, and unlimited times per turn.

Through these actions, you will be able to acquire cards to your hand and draft cards from your hand to your Armada. Each card added to your Armada (ports, forts, ships, and crew) will give you additional actions you may perform each turn. You may not use the actions of cards in your hand, but the cards themselves may be spent in various ways (or drafted to your Armada).

In addition, certain cards (such as most ships) are worth between 1 to 4 victory points. The first player to 8 victory points wins the game.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Gunship: Arsenal!
description:
More options, more fun and tons more destruction! It's the Gunship: Arsenal!

This expansion collects 3 of the previous expansions into one set. Additionally, it adds new carriers to allow proper 4 players games.

This set includes:

From Gunship: First Strike! X-perimental Weapons
80 Upgrade Cards - Awesome new gunship weapons plus fighter and carrier upgrades!

From Gunship: Crewmates!
18 Crewmate Cards - Recruit characters with special abilities to crew your vessels!

From Gunship: Asteroids!
36 Asteroid Cards - New mini-game and battlespace terrain!

From Gunship: Green and White Carrriers
2 Carrier Boards - Unlocks 3-player and 4-player free-for-all modes!

2 12-sided dice - For use with the new carriers!

From Gunship: Tokens Expansion
1 Sheet of Punchboard Tokens - Die-cut ships for more sci-fi theme!
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Push Your Luck

name: Munchkin Tavern Shot Glass
description:
This was a promotional item available at the Munchkin Tavern from the 2013 GenCon.

This may be used with any Munchkin game or the expansions.

Once per game per different style of Munchkin Tavern shot glass, when someone else is losing a combat, you may "take a shot for the team." Take a shot from the Tavern Shot Glass and then roll to Run Away from a single monster on behalf of the player you're helping. If you succeed, or the monster's Bad Stuff would not affect you, then nothing happens. If you fail and the Bad Stuff does affect you, draw a face-down Treasure card after you resolve the Bad Stuff, unless you are Dead.

name: Big Angry Monsters
description: Big Angry Monsters is a board game where players assume the roles of Giant Monsters trying to be the last Monster standing by destroying each other and the Island of Nacob in the process. Players start the game by building the Island of Nacob by randomly placing city tiles on the board, then placing their Monsters in the City Roads or Ocean waters. Monsters will then duke it out with a press your luck dice rolling mechanic where monsters can attack monsters and buildings, do super moves, gain power to buy crazy upgrades and effects in order to be the last Monster standing. Big Angry Monsters will comfortably seat 2-8+ players(more player may need a larger island!) and take between 30 minutes and an hour to play.
categories: City Building, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Gunslingers Card Game
description:
Gunslingers'' is a card game set in the wild west, where each player must build up a posse of gunslingers to fight it out to the death. The player with the last gunslinger left alive wins the game.

During the game set up procedure location cards are randomly placed to create a western town for the players to move around. Each location the players visit opens up options that they can interact with to aid them in building up a strong group of gunslingers.

Starting the game with just one gunslinger card each, the players must move around the town and reach specific locations to play action cards, hire gunslingers or buy and sell items or weapons in an effort to build up their posse and eventually shoot it out to the death.

By buying Items or weapons the players can enhance their gunslingers abilities during specific actions, such as giving a gunslinger a holster during a shoot out action will make them faster on the draw.

The action cards get the players gambling at the saloon, mining at the mine, brawling outside the sheriffs office and capturing gunslingers from the rival posses, only then marching them off to the gallows and sending the prisoner to boot hill. Many more actions cards exist that can change the strategies of the game, like the explosion card, that could blow up the train station and thus prevent the only place the players can go to hire more gunslingers, their only choice would be to wait until it was rebuilt.

As soon as one player has hired a gunslinger from the train station, the fighting can begin so you had better earn some cash fast and be that first player or you may be sent to boot hill sooner than you think........
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Gen D'Armes: Rules for a Medieval Wargame
description:
Late Medieval/Early Renaissance wargame rules that use a map-based simultaneous movement system to indicate where units will move each turn. A unit's status is tracked on a simple roster that records losses to the unit. Troops also have an assigned relative points value that can be used for play-balance.

Shooting resolution uses a number of six-sided dice (D6), while melee resolution uses the cumulative melee values of the stands engaged multiplied by the result of a single average die (2-3-3-4-4-5) and the totals compared. There is also shock combat resolution to take account of the impetus of charging troops.

A stand of miniatures is removed after a specific number of roster hits are recorded. The amount required varies by the type of unit; for example, peasants remove a stand for every two hits, while knights remove stands after five hits.

Gen D'Armes is a playable set of rules that has stood the test of time and uses some well thought-out mechanics. There is also a section for siege battles.

name: Pirate Rush
description:
Players enlist a pirate crew trying to get the most valuable loot at the end of the game.
Pirate Rush is a role selection game for 2-4 players of about 45 minutes long.

34 treasure tiles are arranged in eight piles (the isles).
Each turn the players will select a role (wich give them different powers for the turn), get information about treasures in the map and get a loot from the island they are in.

Tiles can have positive or negative values, and a bluff, strategy and some deduction skills can make the difference between a rich pirate and a poor and doomed one.

A new resource mechanics and event has been implemented to get an even more estrategic game.

The website is in spanish, but the game isn't language dependant and english rules are available to download.
April 2015 actualization: The final rules are finally translated and reference cards are in english too)

name: Zombify: Dead City
description:
Africa was first to disapear when unknown virus hits there as epicentrum. But it was only a few days before Asia and Europe to fall. US try to fight as efficient as they can - closed borders, no ship or plane can land... but it just wasn't enough.

On the last, seperated city few survivers trying to hold on in the shelter of old town center, but lack of supplies and problems that appears force them to move outside risking thier lives and trying to make a contact and call for rescue...

In Zombify: Dead City, the players take the role of survivers in the city full of zombies - their every move and every action can bring more zombies on board and they just have to survive till the rescue comes... but who will be rescue?

During their turns players can explore the city in the search for supplies, special items or solve problems that affects gameplay. They are using custom dice to fight and solve actions. After few days they can call for rescue and if they defend their shelter - they will be extracted and wins.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Hop
description:
Hop is an abstract strategy game with simple rules and generic material. An 8x8 board, 16 black and 16 white stones is all you need.

Starting with your stones on the first 2 lines of your side of the board your goal is to move one of your stones to the opponent's end. To get there stones can only move by jumping vertically or horizontally over at least one adjacent stone (or a row of stones) of any color composition onto the next free field. But be careful! Finding the right balance between offense and defense is key. Because whenever you don't jump forward on your turn, your opponent may say "Hop", forcing you to a second move that MUST be forward. But using the "Hop" rule in the right moment yourself can free the way to victory!

Find the complete rules in the Files section.

name: Mage Wars: Summoning Circle Promo Card
description:
First distributed at BashCon 2013

Whenever your Mage summons a creature, he may place it in Summoning Circle's zone instead of his own zone, regardless of range or LoS.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: Mage Wars: Spiked Buckler Promo Card
description: Mage gains a Defense. Whenever this Defense successfully avoids an attack, Spiked Buckler's attack gains the Counterstrike trait until the end of that attack sequence.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: Mage Wars: Sandstorm Promo Card
description:
First distributed Origins 2013.

If pushed, roll for random direction.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Stella Nova: Journey of the Magi
description:
Stella Nova: Journey of the Magi is a race to see which of the wise men (magi), who have seen a new star (stella nova), can be the first to safely reach the Christ child in Bethlehem with the three gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh.

Magi ride camels along the caravan trails from the Far East to Bethlehem. Each roll represents one day in the journey. Magi must carry enough food and water (Supply Cards) to get to the next city or oasis. For each daily roll, the magi must turn in a Supply Card. If the magi run out of supply cards on the trail, then they must go back and replenish their supplies.

The magi must overcome hazards on the dangerous caravan trails as they cross over mountains and through deserts, such as: blinding sand storms, attacks by robber bands, fog and clouds that obscure the guiding star, and hidden assassin spies. These obstacles can be overcome with the right cards: Tent Cards for sand storms, Weapons Cards for robbers, Compass Cards for fog, and Secret Code Cards for spies. These Equipment Cards can be obtained at different cities on the trails in the North-- if one can answer a trivia question. The player can choose from two types of questions: History & Geography, or Biblical Scriptures. Young children can play without having to answer the questions.

So as well as a Race Game, Stella Nova is a Strategy Game where players must decide which is the most efficient path to take, and what resources and equipment to keep and what to leave behind.

Of course the magi must also obtain the three precious gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh to give to the Christ child. These Gift Cards are only available a specific cities in the South.

Magi can capture a wild stallion at the oases and get a Wild Stallion Card. These cards can provide an advantage, such as racing ahead or jumping over other magi, or can give a disadvantage to an opponent, such as going back three spaces.

Stella Nova is a great Party Trivia game too. Players demonstrate their knowledge by answering questions on Biblical history and geography to obtain the needed Equipment and Gifts Cards.

Note: Stella Nova is an Educational Game for students, because it's historically and geographically accurate. The cities have their ancient names from the time of Christ. For example, Yathrib in Arabia is called Medina today. It was renamed by the Muslim prophet Mohamed in about 622 AD.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Ancient, Racing, Religious, Trivia

name: Topsy Turvy
description:
A fast-pace game of memorizing words and being bossed around by a deck of cards! Topsy Turvy forces you to remember a sequence of words created by the players while trying to draw cards following their simple yet distracting instructions.

Will you master the art of memorization? Or will you break the sequence and turned Topsy Turvy!

Topsy Turvy is a sequence memory game that challenges players in their skill of memory. Players decide who goes first, then that player decides on the first word of the sequence and draws a card. This card determines which player gets the next turn. That players says the sequence, adds a word, and draws a card.

Sometimes, a card does not simply determines the next player, though, but tries to throw off the players' train of though, such as the "Erase" card that deletes any word of the current player's choice.

name: La Grande Corsa nello Spazio
description:
Galassia is a space racing game of the 80s in which each player must be able to build a path from Earth to the planets that were randomly assigned at the beginning of the game, through the placement of the space lanes tiles.

Each player also tries to hinder other players in their purpose. They also have strategic cards at their disposal, which can help a player get past space lanes closed by his opponents.

The spacecraft, which can be moved by all the players, move from Earth to the planets with the spinner.

Players get points for arriving at the planets, with players who arrive earliet getting more points. The game ends when everyone has reached their destination; the player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Micro Machines Car Chase Board Game
description:
Catch the traffic lights and chase your opponents off the track and out of the game. Ages 6 and over.

Includes card playing pieces but use your own Micro Machines vehicles for added realism.

name: Graham Kennedy's Blankety Blanks
description:
(Not to be confused with the UK game show just simply called Blankety Blank even though the two formats are quite identical to one another.) is based on the formerly popular Network 10 hit game show, hosted by the late Graham Kennedy from 1977-1979 followed by Daryl Somers from 1985-1986 and Shane Bourne from 1996-1997 later on Nine Network. (for which in turn was adapted from the hit US Game Show 'Match Game').

to set-up
1. elect a compere (for best results, pick a witty friend)
2. Place panel wallet so that the opening is at the top.
3. Put stiffener board. Place Key Cards in front of the game cards, place one on each side in such a way that no word can be seen in the windows under the panelists.

Order of play
1.Compere selects 2 contestants - A or B.
2.Compere asks contestant A the question which appears on the 'Contestant A' side at the top of the panel wallet.
For Example: in game 1 (Tom Thumb lost his "BLANK" while riding on a yo-yo).
3. Contestant A substitutes a word for 'BLANK' in doing so, Contestant A tries to guess the answers given by the panel.
4.Having announced his/her guess the compere slowly (revealing only one answer at a time) removes the key card.
Contestant A now knows how many of the panel agrees with his choice and scores that number accordingly.
5. The procedure is repeated for Contestant B.
6. Should a tied score result - the following game is then played.
7. The winner is entitled to play Super Match.
8.Compere picks up Super Match card and asks the contestant to respond a word (e.g. for Game 1 use the word 'FACE'. For Game 2 use 'BABY' etc.)
9.Contestant may ask all others at the table for help. Prize money is paid dependent upon which response the contestant selects corresponding to the three previous selected answers, (e.g. Word 1 'FACE', If Contestant says 'FACE MASK' he/she wins $50.
10.If the contestant gives one of the three answers (i.e. Pack. Mask or Life, he/she is entitled to play for the Jackpot Match.
11.If none of the three words is selected, the game finishes and another contestant is selected to play against the winner.
(NOTE: The two number '9's' are actually listed on the instruction card.)

Jackpot Match
1.Compere gives both the contestants and himself a pad and pencil.
2.Compere reads out the word (e.g. Game 1 - he reads Comic).
3.Compere and contestant each secretly respond on paper (e.g. Comic Book or Comic Strip). If the answers are identical, the contestant wins 10x his/her winnings from the immediate preceding Super Match round.
4.The game is thus completed and a new contestant is selected to compete against the current champion.
(NOTE: After completing Game 1, remove question card from wallet and lay face up on the table - then place Game 2 when completed on top, and so on. When the wallet is empty, turn the whole set of questions upside down and place them all back in the wallet - Remember to replace the Key Cards.)

name: Tjejmiddag
description:
Swedish party game (translation "Girls' dinner").

A simple trivia game with 400 questions on topics like the perfect boyfriend, fun memories, sex and much more.

The game is more about having fun than keeping score, but as is customary in these types of games, one correct answer scores one point.

name: Oil Strike!
description:
Oil Strike! is played on a board depicting an oil field divided into areas of two, three, and four sites. Players start with one area (size depending on turn order) and claim a new one each turn as long as they last. The other thing a player does on each turn is select one of their sites and roll two dice, with a high enough roll producing oil and a lower roll condemning it to be dry.

Drilling next to producing wells (no matter who owns them) adds a point to the die roll for each such well, making it easier to strike oil. Players can (before rolling the dice) declare that they are going for double or quadruple production, which requires higher rolls.

Players score points for producing wells (more for double or quadruple wells, of course) and bonus points for getting all sites in an area to produce. The first player to reach a target score wins, or the player with the most points if no one manages that.

name: Swish
description:
Swish is played on a 8x8 board using two pieces per player and 19 neutral pieces. The object of the game is to capture ten of the neutral pieces.

The players' pieces are placed anywhere on the outer edge of the board and the neutral pieces anywhere not on the outer edge. However, the player setting up the board does not have to place all the neutral pieces; after placement the other player decides whether to go first and choose the color to play, or to go second and take all the neutral pieces not placed.

On a turn a player moves a piece any distance in a straight line, ending on an empty space. However, either neutral or opposing pieces (but not both) may be jumped as long as they are all adjacent to each other; there may be empty spaces before or after them.

name: SpongeBob: Krabby Patty
description:
SpongeBob - Krabby Patty is an action game in which players have to complete first the Krabby Patty hamburger.

Game play:
In the middle of the table there are SpongeBob and the Krabby Patty ingredients.
During his turn, each player rolls the dice and try to win an ingredient.
The player who does first the requested activity, according to the dice, wins an ingredient.
For example, players must:
- Take SpongeBob
- Take the dice
- Stand up, turn around and take SpongeBob
- Stand up, turn around the table and take the dice
- Stand up and say “Holy Krabby Patties!”

The player who has all the ingredients first, is the winner.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Trivial Pursuit: The Power Rangers 20th Anniversary Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

It's time to power up for some morphinominal fun! Do you know the name of Zordon's sidekick? How about the name of the Red Samurai Ranger's signature weapon? Or can you name 3 Power Ranger seasons with the world "force" in it? Blast into the Power Rangers universe in this special Power Rangers 20th Anniversary Edition of TRIVIAL PURSUIT. For the first time ever, the Power Rangers team up with America's favorite trivia game so fans of all ages can test their knowledge of these legendary heroes with 1,800 questions covering the Power Rangers gear, the allies and villains they faced, their morphing powers and more.

As in other Trivial Pursuit games, players roll dice to move around the board and answer trivia questions in various categories. Players earn pieces by answering correctly on certain spaces for each category, and the winner is the first to collect one of every piece and return to the middle and answer one final question.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Tudor Galleons at War
description: Tudor Galleons at War represents a sea battle between old enemies, England and France, at the beginning of modern naval warfare in the Tudor period. Three classes of ship each with differing degrees of orthogonal and diagonal movement. Capture is custodial but depends on the size of the ships capturing and the ship being captured. Winner is the player with the most points in the navy that survives the battle. Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

name: Tram: Spel
description: Tram-Spel (Tram game) is about horsecars and was made in the early 1900's by Werner & Schumann, Berlin. It is typical roll and move board game. The first player who cross 63 stops, wins the game.

name: Dr√≠bling
description:
Juego de simulación de un partido de baloncesto.
El juego traía un tablero que representaba una cancha de baloncesto.
Cada jugador dirigía dos equipos, y tenían que jugar todo el partido, resolviéndose todas las situaciones con tiradas de dados.

Simulation game of a basketball game. The game has a board depicting a basketball court. Each player runs two teams, and they have to play the entire game, solving all situations with dice rolls.

Dribling is a basketball simulation game which is situated halfway between classic board games, strategy or letters. Each participating player takes the role of coach and can design a complete basketball team and fully tailored from the creation of the various players. Source: Publisher's website

name: Skirmish! The Scrambles plus expansions pack
description:
User summary:

A special release of Skirmish! The Scrambles containing both expansion packs Antimagic and Breakthrough for Essen Spiel 2013.

name: Dogfight D6's: An Aerial Combat, Dice Rolling Game
description:
Take to the skies in a tabletop dogfight! Players take turns rolling dice to soar across the board, attempting to shoot down their opponent's planes while using evasive maneuvers or returning fire. With 12 2-sided, shiftable sky panels that make up the game board, an Event deck that alters battlefield conditions, and the option of choosing to play as 1 of 8 unique pilots instead of a basic ship, no 2 Dogfight games will be the same!

About Dogfight D6's: Whatever version, Dogfight D6's is a dice rolling, aerial combat themed game which was designed to allow for competitive players while still providing appeal to gamers who prefer less wordy, "quick pick up and play" kinds of games. The objective remains the same for either audience (roll dice to move and shoot down planes), however, the rules are written to allow players of both audiences to participate in the same game and enjoy it without being imbalanced towards either one.

Features in this Version:


2 sided, interchangable playing field pieces- each has 1 "all blue spaces" side and 1 "cloud patterns" side, allowing for a different playing field each game!



Plane tokens for up to 8 players, although the rules are structured to allow for more players.



Pilot Cards and Custom Pilot Setup Rules- Now choose either the Basic Pilot Setup (all Stats are set at 2 with no abilities) or use these rules/cards to play a game with unique abilities and rolled Stats.



Event Cards-Cards which affect gameplay and battlefield conditions as long as they are active.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Splush
description:
Splush is a group-gathering game for Shibumi that uses entries and slide drops. The board starts as shown below:

‚óè ‚óã ‚óè ‚óã
‚óã ‚óè ‚óã ‚óè
‚óè ‚óã ‚óè ‚óã
‚óã ‚óè ‚óã ‚óè

Players then take turns either:


Entering a ball of their color from the side onto a 2x2 platform, which may push other balls, or



Removing a ball of their color and entering it back into play as per move 1; this removal may cause a drop.


Entering a ball may cause a drop but may not push any balls off the board. You cannot enter a ball onto any ball that has just
dropped as part of the move. A player wins by connecting all of their visible balls (when viewed from above) into a single connected group.

name: Ascension: Rise of Vigil ‚Äì Mistress of Blades Promo Card
description:
The Mistress of Blades is a promo for Ascension: Rise of Vigil that was released during the summer and fall of 2013. It was given out at conventions as well.

Cost: 3 runes
Value: 2 honor

Text on card:
Gain 2 power
Whenever you defeat a Monster in the center row this turn, draw a card.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management

name: Sulphur
description:
From the company website:

The game is played out between forces composed of several vehicles and infantry squads per side. Each vehicle has a number of design options regarding which weapons are selected, engine size and various offensive and defensive accoutrements such as extra armour, targeting devises, smoke dischargers etc. This means that players can create very different vehicles from the same chassis.
With the infantry we have divided them into a number of categories such as Light Infantry, Assault Infantry, Warriors and Heavy Weapons. Each category has a defined profile, a set of stats, weapons and armour that help it conform to their definition. This means that each type of squad has a particular function on the battlefield.

Light troops for instance move fast across the battlefield are good at scouting out the enemies dispositions and also getting out of trouble fast. Assault troops are designed to get in close with the enemy - they have the armour and firepower to take the fight to their opponents. The Warriors role is obviously to make contact with the enemy and destroy them in deadly hand-to-hand fighting. And Heavy Weapons teams are designed to hang back a bit and support forward units with heavy long-range fire.

Players will therefore need to learn how to use their troops to their best advantage as well as how to combine them with other squads in their force for maximum efficiency and effect. For instance, using light troops to identify targets, using heavy weapons to weaken and suppress the target and then sending in the warriors to finish them off at close quarters. Sounds easy? Not so in practise! What this simply means that it is not just a case of the dude with the biggest gun winning the day (although the game does have plenty of big guns!). The right troops have to be used at the right time in the right way.

The game also includes a number of leader types. These are heroes with certain special skills that will boost the performance of the force. Some of these figures might be just great individual fighters, others may have leadership skills that can enhance the power of the rest of the force.

What is very apparent to players is the amount of choice that they have in creating their force, from vehicle design to infantry squad selection and leader choice. A different army can be assembled for every game.
Most battles will be fought over very challenging terrain. All manner of risks and rewards can be found - from hidden obstacles, explosive and flammable materials but also extra ammunition and weapons. The terrain always plays its part in games of Sulphur.

Another vital component to the game is the use of Asset Cards. These are played and collected during the game to further enhance the performance of a force. Each card is specific to a certain troop type (for example light squad, leader, vehicle etc). Each card will award the player a special skill or piece of equipment that will benefit that squad (and hopefully encourage the player to use the squad to its maximum advantage). These Asset Cards can have great significance in the game and add to the players burden of command and decision making - but they are a lot of fun too, especially when they thwart the plans of your opponent.

And from time to time there are the deadly and unpredictable incursions of Sulphur. The deadly field of battle is made even more challenging by this unholy threat. Will the combatants form a temporary truce and turn their guns on this new and devastating threat or will they abandon their opponents, withdraw from the field and let them face the terror alone? The menace of Sulphur hangs over every battlefield like a cloud. Most times it does not appear - but the fear and unease that it generates is ever present…

name: Paperclip Railways: Zelig Suberb
description:
Bonus station card (#23). Base game has three 'placeholder' station cards that can be cashed in for a promo of choice 'from the box'.

It was given in Essen 2011 for the buyers of the base game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Territory Building, Trains
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: 7ombieTV
description:
“There are only five of us now, three of us didn’t make it when we ran into them on the other side of the stream. None of us wants to think that they are following us, mindless, only wanting to feast on our flesh, but we cannot stop thinking of the horror behind us.
We are all shocked and exhausted but we must keep going. The trees are thinning out and I can see lights ahead… we’ve almost made it… A farm surrounded by bushes but with lights on, there must be other survivors there. No, not bushes – the house is surrounded by dozens of zombies, trying to break in. I can hear their moans even this far away, they sound so close.
They are among the trees. Shambling over dead wood, we are surrounded…”

7ombieTV is a standalone Zombie horror spinoff from acclaimed spy-fi miniatures game 7TV. It is the 1980s, and the dead have risen with terrifying amounts of gore and a fearsome appetite for your flesh! Only with a bold heart and a large amount of unlikely weaponry can you survive the night…

Players make their force spending points and following rules on the number of heroes and sheep they can have as there are three levels of characters. The game is won when one side completes the objective, points can be scored for other task completed during the game such as killing of zombies! Elements can be used in the 7TV games if desired.

name: Elephonkey
description:
From the box back:

ELEPHONKEY The game where the truth has a major deficit

Everybody’s full of Elephonkey in this not-really-political party game!

Play your hand and lay down your cards, announcing their ranks… are you gonna tell the truth? Maybe… and maybe not! Donkeys, Elephants, Tree-Huggers and Tea Partiers are the “suits” and there are a couple special interest porkers mixed in.

If you think somebody’s lying about the cards they play, shout, “ELEPHONKEY!” Be first to get rid of your cards and you’ll have a landslide victory!

name: Palacio de Viana: Las llaves de palacio
description:
With the keys, the closed door at the Palacio could be not a problem...

Contains 5 key tiles (one per player) and rules.

With a key, you can pass through the door of the basic game, and one of the character (Ama de llaves) gives you one additional VP.

Free promo item at the Festival Internacional de Juegos Córdoba 2012.
publishers: Festival Internacional de Juegos de C√≥rdoba, Jugamos Tod@s

name: Â≠êËÇ≤„Å¶„Éâ„É©„Ç¥„É≥
description:
Â≠êËÇ≤„Å¶„Éâ„É©„Ç¥„É≥, which translates to "child-rearing dragon" was published in the doujinshi magazine „Å§„Åé„ÅØ„Åé„Åü„Çà„Çä in 2007, which was available in a PDF version for international download shopping from after 2008 until 2013.

In the game, the players take on the roles of dragon mothers who are stuck in human form until their respective child has reached adulthood or died (the latter does not occur in the game). Therefore, challenges have to be overcome by the child or the mother-child combination. Being published in an RPG doujinshi, the game has a lot of flavor text/descriptions.

The players decide when to rest or when to move to a different location (from a set of 6 locations), but otherwise is dependent on the luck of the roll. Each turn (defined as 10 years), unless the mother is resting, a die is rolled to determine the needs of the child and the mother then has to match or come within 1 of that die result. Success leads to a roll on a positive event table (modified by the care attribute/skill) while failure leads to a roll on the risky event table for the current location (which are often but not always negative events). In addition, after handling the events, the player may move the family to an adjacent location.
At the end of each turn, tiredness is checked to see whether the next turn is spent resting. When playing with 2+ players, players in the same location may attack each other to steal loot from each other.

The first player to lead the child to adulthood (which requires 20 units of loot) wins the game. Solo play is mentioned as an option, but no special rules are provided and some of the possible player powers are incompatible with solo play.

name: ASL Comp: Fire and Ice
description:
(from the introduction and user's description:)

The three majors wars of Finland are represented by scenarios in this product: Winter war, Continuation war and Lapland war. There is also a bonus scenario that depicts action from "Vapaussota" (Finland's war of independence in 1918).

Fire & Ice is essentially a combined and revised reprint of two previous scenario packs: 1996's Jatkosota and 2004's Finland at War.

Components:

special rules (8 pages)
2 identical countersheets
4 winterized maps (W1, W2, W3, W4)
1 8x11" overlay map (no identification on it)
25 scenarios (1 in 1919, 8 in 1939-40, 7 in 1941, 1 in 1942, 1 in 1943, 7 in 1944)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Royal Assassin
description:
Your father, the king, united four small fiefdoms into a mighty kingdom. Now that he is dead, the former royal families of those fiefdoms are plotting to take over the throne that is rightfully yours. You are outnumbered, but in your struggle to defeat them you have a powerful ally: your court jester, the Joker, who as your father's friend and advisor was always much more than he appeared to be. He is highly skilled at court intrigue, and can help set them all against one another so that you can retain your throne. He is your secret weapon - your Royal Assassin!
